Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Sammy wanted to go to where the people were.  Where might he go? Choices:  A: race track B: populated areas C: the desert D: apartment E: roadblock<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>-A: apartment<n><n>-B: populated areas<n><n>### Input :<n><n>"Kayla's dad has always been afraid of flying. However, that didn't stop him from flying Kayla to Hawaii on vacation. He took with him his old copy of the book "1001 Best Places to Fly" and said, "Kayla, I think it's time you read the first book I ever read about flying." After looking it up, Kayla found out it had 430 pages. Kayla, who is also afraid of flying, now feels that she may be able to overcome her fear after reading the book."<n><n>### Response :<n>Kayla will probably overcome her fear of flying.<n>

Choices:  A: hospital B: head C: sick person D: elderly person E: doctor's office<n><n>### Response:		If a sick person goes to the doctor's office, there is a 100% chance that the person will contract illness. So, the doctor's office is the right answer.<n><n>### Input 2: What is a method to write a program that uses the conditional statement if? Choices:  a: make a counter b: use the loop c: use the conditional statement if d: none of the above<n><n>### Response<n>B: Use the Loop<n><n>In a loop, the program will run the statements inside the loop. In a while loop, use a counter or a number to check if a condition is true.<n><n>### ACT Question:<n><n>In the loop given below, the i variable should be which number so that the statements inside the statements can be evaluated?<n><n>i = 2. while( i<=4);<n><n>### Demolition:<n><n>If the statements inside of the while loop are evaluating correctly at the end, the answer is 3.<n><n>### Response 2:<n><n>If the statement inside of the loop is evaluating, then the correct answer should be 2.<n><n>### Test Question:<n><n>The values of the variables in the statements of the program should be <n><n>### Demos:<n><n>The variables inside the loop should have values to evaluate if a condition for the loop should run a loop.<n><n>### Answer 3:<n><n>Input: You are writing a program that prints numbers from 5 to 12. But you really only want to print 7, 9, 11. How many numbers will actually be printed? Choices: <n><n>1.0, 6.0, 6, -8, -6, -2, 2.<n><n>2.9, 3, -1, -10, 11, 12, 12, -10, -9, -8<n><n>3.12<n><n>4.15<n><n>### Demotion:<n><n>The numbers will count from five to 12 without counting the numbers 7, 9 or 11.<n><n>### Explanation of Demand:<n><n>The program should return value 12.<n><n><n><n>### Test:<n><n><n><n>

I am a place in New York famous for many people, famous buildings, and people who are just famous in general. I am also an apple variety. What am I?<n>### 2. I am a fruit that begins with the letter "w" and I come from a tree. If every can gave me an income of $0.5 and every 5 more kilograms, the income was $1.5, then it's a total of income $120.<n><n>### Explanatino - 2:After Matthew picked 16 stawbrries, Betty picked 16 more and Matthew picked 42 more than, Natalie didn't pick strawberries because she didn't pick any at all. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:What is a good result of jogging? Choices:  A: insect repellent B: heart attacks C: improved health D: shin splints E: being tired<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Input<n>The following program lists the amount of money earned from recycling and cleaning up trash. Write a function getNetMoney() that returns the net amount of money earned, which is the amount earned after deducting cleaning fees.<n><n><n>    getCleaningFee(amountRecycled);    // returns cleaning fee per amount of recycled items<n>    getNetMoney();                    // returns net amount of money earned<n><n>### Response<n>    def getNetMoney():        # Returns 0 for a loss, and a number in dollars for a profit<n>        $$recCycling = 0.50     # Dollars earned per 12 cans<n>        $$cleaningFee = 0.55    # Dollars lost per cleaning<n>                                # 0.5 is cleaning fee, and 0.55 is cleaning fee per amount<n>        $$totalRecycling = 12.00 # Amount of cans<n>                                # (Total of cans =.5/5, or in decimal format, it is 0.5)<n>        $$totalCleaning = 0.5       # Cleaning fee for all cans<n>                                #(Total of cans = 12, then you  have 12(.5/12))<n><n>        print( "Dont't forget to subtract the cleaning fee." )<n>        print("Here's the money you get left = ", $$totalRecycling * $$recCycling - $$totalCleaning * $$cleaningFee)<n>```

Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:What enables most people to transport themselves? They were determined to be born with the freedom to choose their own paths. Freedom has brought them a lot. They have enjoyed a lot of freedom and they have seen the benefits they have achieved. Now they  are in a comfortable life.<n><n>For transportation from one place to another, I used to take the motorcycle, the bus or the car. I used to take my car, it helped me to arrive at my destinations much faster. I used to take the bike for a short distance trip and for short distances it would be much faster than anything else. It would be also more comfortable and faster at certain times of the year. The car is faster and more comfortable.<n><n>For my first degree I used books as transport, and in my next degree I used cars and motorcycles and for going to places far away I used aeroplanes or helicopters or trains. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Where must one wear a white shoe? Choices:  A: wedding B: tennis C: closet D: left foot E: house<n><n>### Response:		F<n><n>### Demostration:<n>If one were to wear white shoes while going to a tennis court, but the court is green, the shoes would be colored (and possibly dirty) by the end of the day and thus would not be any cleaner than if one wore them in the house. Moreover, if you wore the white shoe left foot only, your right foot would be dirty as well from walking around and it would also not be wearing a white sock, so it's not clear to me why the question is asking about white shoes.

He spends 45 minutes on tasks A, 90 minutes on task B, 15 minutes on task C, 60 minutes on task D, and 40 minutes on task E. How much time does he spend on his work overall?<n>### Demostration:<n>Answer: 195 minutes<n><n>Given time stamps corresponding to a given activity, a given interval and a given event.<n><n>### Input<n>*TimeStamp A: 08:03:57 AM*<n>*TimeStamp B: 08:13:10 AM*<n>*Interval (time delta): 00:00:12 hours (00:12 minutes)*<n>*Event: End of interval<n><n>### Demostricaon:<n>**Time Stamp A**=00:00<n>**Time Stamp B**= 00:27<n>**Event**=00:15<n><n>### Inputs:<n>TimeStamp A:<n><n>\[A = 00:05:20\]<n><n>TimeStamp B:<n><n>\[B = 00:20\]<n>Interval (time delta): seconds<n><n>\[d = 00:15\]<n>Event: End of interval.<n><n>### Demo:<n>The answer for this would be a function f where the input is (A,B,d) and the output is the newStamp (and maybe other interesting bits). The function would look something like the formula f=A-B which could easily be programmed in pseudo-code to produce g:<n><n>f = A - B<n><n>The result could then be calculated by performing the formula and making a simple logical process to make the answer A.<n><n>### Response<n>A=A-B<n>So to produce an answer we would have to do the following<n><n>\[g(\mathbf A') =

Choose from the options.<n><n> -   Everyone is more interested in A vs B C D E<n> -   One thing is more interesting than the other<n> -   Everyone prefers B over A<n><n>Answer: -   Everyone is More Interested in a<n><n>### Instructiom:<n>Which statement would be true if option E was false?<n><n> -   One thing over another<n> -   A B and C together, or something else<n> -   Someone is interested in<n><n>- C is true because if one were false C would be the only true answer.<n><n>### Inputs:<n>Input: Find the missing number (25, 32, __32__, 37)<n><n>### Response<n><n> -   40<n><n>### Instutciions:<n>Write one number and question mark at least once<n><n>### Instuctions:<n>A student reads 30 stories for science class each year. Choices:  A: do enjoy B: get laid C: enjoyable D: work less E: enjoy living<n><n>### Response:		If the frat boys shouted that they would have fun, that implies they would enjoy at least one thing. Thus, the correct answer is Choice B (do enjoy).<n><n>### Input<n>What is one of the first things a person should do when working toward a goal?<n>Choices:<n>A: Keep track of where he is every day.<n>B: Keep track of how far he has come.<n>C: Keep track of goals that he has not yet met.<n>D: Keep track of the goals that he has already met.<n>E: Keep track of the steps he has taken toward his goal.<n><n>### Response<n>B) “Keep track of how far he is every day” will help a person keep a record of his progress toward achieving his goal.<n><n>

Choices:  A: nuclear power plant B: center C: basement D: main office E: bowel of the ship<n><n>### Response:		A: nuclear power plant<n><n>### Instructions:Choose the correct answer.<n><n>### Input:[3,2,4,5,2] in reverse order is:<n><n>### Response:[2,5,4,3,2]<n><n>### If a dog eats dog food 50% of the time, and cat food 30% of the time and chicken 20% of the time. If 20% of all the food he ate was chicken, how many hours does he have to sleep to get enough energy?<n><n>### Response:(2x)30+(3x)40=270<n><n>

The price will be rounded to the nearest dollar:<n><n>### Choices: $125<n><n>### Decision:<n><n>### Option 1: Use 4/16 = 0.25 as a ratio. Then, divide 250 by (0.25) = 1,000. Since 1,001 rounds to 1,002, you would actually pay $1,002. This choice has 2 correct steps.<n><n>### Option2: Use 250 for the divisor in the computation. (250/250) is 1. This choice has 1 correct steps.<n><n>After checking, you’ll find 250 for divisor will be the wrong choice.<n><n>### Input & Response:<n><n><n>### Choice <n><n>### Input Choice 1:<n><n>### Input 2:<n><n>### Response 2: A<n><n>### How It Turns Out:<n><n>### Which answer would you go with and why? The main reason for that is because 'cargo ship','refrigerator' and 'food' do not contain the word 'goods', which is required to meet the question requirements. Secondly, after unloading the goods, they are usually 'transported to warehouse' or 'dispatched to another place', not 'port'. I believe I am correct? So far I haven't came across the word transport in relation to unloading goods.<n><n>### Input (2):<n>A man made 9 t-shirts and sold 16 t-shirts. How many of each type of shirt were sold? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Where is a microphone boom likely to be covering a stock market event? Choices:  A: new york B: concert C: tv studio D: gig E: recording studio<n><n>### Response:		A (new york)<n><n><n>### Input : It took me less than 200 pages to read the latest Jane Austen novel. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:What happens to cats every day? Choices:  A: open doors B: drink water C: need food D: annoy E: play<n><n>### Response:		You didn't provide enough information.<n><n>### Input (2):Ali has 30 lollipops. She also knows that each day that she gives out a lollipop that she also receives 1 dollar each. How many dollars does she receive every week?<n><n>### Response (2): 20<n><n>### Description<n><n>Ali has 368 days in a year. She gives the lollipops out as a way to get money so she spends 368 * 30. There is a week that has 7 days. The most she would get a week is for 7 days and that is to give out 7 * 30 =210 which is more than one week. Therefore, the lollipops add up to 368. Ali receives 1 for every one of her lollipops. Since her lollipops are 368 in total, she will receive 368 days.<n><n>### Evaluation<n><n><n>### [Validate](https://peachpit.com/articles/article.aspx?p=1561867).<n><n>### [Approve](https://peachquit.com/article/1561890).<n><n>### References:<n><n>### [Bell Ringer: Multiplication and Division](https://www.khanacademy.org/math/arithmetic/multiplication_division).<n><n>### Sources:<n><n><n>### Questions:<n><n><n>

Choices:  A: injury B: beauty C: late D: mistakes E: annoyed<n><n>### Response:		The groomer will contact you or send you an email with the extended time.<n><n>### Input<n>How much does the first groom cost? Choices: 0$ 1$  5$  10$  20<n><n>### Response<n>The cost is $15<n><n>### Input <n>How long will the grooming take? Choices: 1 hour  2 hours   20 minutes   3 hours<n><n>### Response <n>It is an average of 3 hours<n><n>## Description<n>A groomer might charge extra when a grooming is more complicated than usual, and she might have to spend more time than anticipated. The groomer estimates that one grooming takes, on average, a minimum of two and a half half hours. She usually charges half the hour rate for each fifteen minutes, and she charges one dollar additional per extra thing that goes wrong or more. For example, if the groomer thinks that a grooming will take at least 105 minutes, she would charge at least:<n><n>The groomer is asked what happens to the next appointment if a grooming takes longer. She says she will contact you or send an email with the extended expected or actual time. She also estimates that a grooming will usually take between 115 and 135 minutes and charges $30.<n><n>## Solution<n>Here's my solution<n><n>```java<n>import java.util.Scanner;<n>public class Groomer{<n>	//This function will ask the user for the grooming time<n>	public static void getGroomingTime(Scanner sc){<n>		System.out.print("How long will the groom take? ");<n>		Sc.nextDouble();<n>		}<n>	}<n>	//This function gets the cost of groom<n>	public static double getGroomingCost(float cost, double time){<n>		double sum = 0;<n>		for (double i = 1; i <= time; i += 0.50){<n>			System

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:What does moving cars entail? Choices:  A: driving B: road C: getting tired D: accidents E: ticket<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>C<n>1.<n>123<n>2.<n>10<n>3.<n>2<n>4.<n>8<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>- Input 1: A<n>- Input 1.2: A<n>- Input B. Input C: A<n>- Input E: C<n>- Solution: Every 12 cars move a few inches per minute.<n><n>### Input 1: What does moving cars entail<n><n>### Input E: A<n><n>### Solution 1: Moving cars entail<n>Every 12 cars move about an inch per minute.<n><n>The total number of cars in a tank can be calculated as follows:<n><n>1. Multiply the number of tickets by 12, then divide it by 8.<n>2. To calculate the ticket, add each tank and multiply it by the number of pins.<n>	- The number of tanks that can fit in the tank is based on how many tanks per inch per minute. The more the tanks, the better the chances of a tank.<n>3. The number of tickets is determined by dividing the number of pins per tank by the number of tickets.<n>	- The more pins, the harder the chances are of a tank.<n>4. The number of pins and tanks is the same in both cases, and the same number is used in both cases by dividing the number pins by the number of pills per ticket.<n>	- We do not expect the number of tickets to be the same, but the same number is expected.<n>	- This is the same in the cases of driving and getting pins.<n>		- Driving is an activity, which involves pins, so the number of pins and tickets will be the same.<n>	- Therefore, 15 tanks can fit in the tank.<n>	<n><img src="figures/car_movement0.png"/><n><n>### Input D: A<n><n>## Solution 2: Moving cars entails<n>There are always 4 cars moving.<n><n>There are 12 cars in a tank. So in 10 minutes, 250 cars per tank.<n><n>The number of pins in a tank is 1500.<n><n>So you can expect 15 tanks to fit into

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Sarah thought that she had been home all evening.  That meant that the only time to leave was when? Choices:  A: early morning B: day time C: night D: afternoon E: daytime<n><n>### Response:		<n>[Choices:  A: night](108), [Choices:  B: early morning](80), [Choices: C: daytime](72), [Choices: D: afternoon](64), [Choices: E: daytime](56)<n><n><n>```javascript<n>function multipleChoiceQuestion (str) {<n>  let str = str.replace(/[^\d]/g,'');<n>  let array = [];<n><n>  for(i=0,j=str.length; i<j; i++) {<n>    if(str[i]! = '\n') {<n>      array.push(str[i]);<n>    } else {<n>      return(array.join(""));<n>    }<n>  }<n>}<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: article B: adjective C: interjection D: conjunction E: pronoun<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: article<n><n>- In English, the preposition "or" would be used to connect the two words "good" and "bad." For example, you are talking about "good vs. bad." Another acceptable response would be to use "of."<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: Hello, I am having a dinner party next weekend. I have invited some of my favorite people in the world who I have known for years. This is a list of people: I have invited Ben, James, Daniel, and Emma.  What preposition would fit best in this situation? I have invited Ben, a really good friend who I met when I was in 5th grade. I have invited Emma, a really pretty blonde who I met when I first moved to this city in 2013. I have invited Daniel, another one of my good friends since middle school. I have invited James, who is actually my fiancé.<n>Answer: of<n><n>### Instructions:Answer two of the following four questions.<n><n>### Answer to Question A<n>A) What is the best word to fill in the blank in the sentence below? The best answer will be either "a" or "an." A: The ________ waved at me this morning on my way to the office.<n><n>### Response A<n>In English, the word A: "a" is best because it is the correct word and the best word to fill the blank.<n><n>The prefix "a-" which changes the sound of the word "the" in English is also the prefix used to make the words "an" when used as an article.<n><n>An example of how an article can be used is: "I want to sell the horse _______ is my horse now." Where "a" would not be the best answer because "an" is the correct word.<n><n>- If you need to memorize the different prefixes, take a look at the prefixes and articles chart [here](/2018-01-29-prefixes-and-articles-chart).<n><n>### Answer To Question B<n>B) Which of the words below is a proper pronoun? Answer: C: I was eating a very tasty meal of mac-and-cheese, but when I turned around I ______.<n><n>### Demstration B<n>C: The

Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Where should you find a school in? Choices:  A: residential neighborhood B: mosque C: every city D: prague E: community<n><n>### Response:		Your question is very vague. You need to give more specific instructions as to where the school should be located. For example: In front of 2013255, behind 202098, or in any 3539933 street in the capital city of 1130000.<n><n># I feel it is worth noting here that the question isn’t grammatically correct.<n><n>### Input : What year is it? Choices: A: 1970 B: 2084787 C: 1974 D: 1982 E: 1990 F: 207786 G: 1991 H: 1997 I: 2003 J: What kind of a question is this? K: I have no idea.<n><n>### Response 1: I don’t know. I only have 4th grade mathematics skills.<n><n>### Respons 2: It is not 2077, I don’t think.<n><n>### I could not provide any more information than that.<n><n>### Answer: It is 2022.<n><n>I am going to assume that your intention is for the responses to be humorous, but I hope that by providing these two examples helps to improve clarity in your writing. By providing examples written by a chat bot might increase the likelihood that your AI has context in which to generate your responses. If the data is not relevant, it is easy to ignore or disregard it, and the data will not be used in the AI generation. To avoid situations like this it is important to check data beforehand to make sure that your data is worth learning from. Some AI’s create irrelevant data from irrelevant input. This is where the creators make mistakes in their choice to model certain types of scenarios. If the situation is highly context dependent and relies on prior historical context, this might not be necessary as it might provide sufficient information to infer what the context is and the responses generated. However, for my case, we are not dealing with complex context dependent situations and would therefore need to explicitly provide the context before the learning could be modelled and inferences could then be generated.<n><n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:What is the result of instituting civil action? Choices:  A: bad feelings B: confusion C: going to court D: hurt feelings E: sandwiches<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The result of instituting a civil law suit is the instituting of a civil court case. If the court case cannot be amicably settled then the suit can be brought into civil proceedings. A civil action is instituted through the invoking of the court. This process may ultimately cause bad feelings because legal actions can be long, costly and ultimately have negative outcomes (if the lawsuit is lost).<n><n>## TFQ:What is the difference between civil and criminal court?<n><n>### Input<n><n>The criminal court is a court where criminal prosecution is brought.<n><n>The civil court is a court where a lawsuit is brought civilly.<n><n>### Response<n><n>One difference is that the criminal court and the civil court are different because they have different purposes, one being to bring about criminal prosecution and the other being to bring a law suit. Second, another difference is that they use different rules of evidence: at the civil trial, you can only use evidence on points you have pleaded, for example, if you claim that the defendant was drunk, then you can only use circumstantial evidence - however, in the criminal trial, you may only use whatever evidence you have at hand, which may not be relevant.<n><n>### Question<n><n>If John Smith is brought to be tried at a criminal court, the defendant would have __________ to plead guilty or to take the case to trial.<n><n>### Answer<n><n>John Smith would be given the chance to plead guilty or plead 'not guilty'. If he pleads guilty then the criminal case ends. If he chooses not to plead guilty then the case goes to trial. A criminal trial is one that is conducted by a judge and a jury.<n><n>### Why do I need to learn all these rules for civil service and civil actions?<n><n>Answers: Because you need to know the rules for civil suit so you can make informed decisions. I would also like you to have this information if you plan to be a civil service lawyer in future.<n><n>### In class today we reviewed civil suits and why we need to get one.<n><n>Answers (1): You can seek compensation for damages, or, to prove that a civil wrong has been done.<n><n>Ans: Because a civil case is often more expensive, so you first need to hire a lawyer

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:What is something that you feel when you go to the opera? Choices:  A: fall asleep B: headache C: boredom D: relaxation E: sick<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n><n>import random<n># Import Random Library.<n>def read_input(string)<n>    try:<n>        return int(input(string))<n>    except:<n>        pass<n><n><n>def print_multiple_choice_question(question_content)<n>    print(question_content) # Print the question.<n>    choice_arr=[k.lower()for k in range(0, question_content.lower().size())]<n>    print("Choices:", choice_arr) # Print choices for the question.<n>    try:<n><n>        # Get the Answer.<n>        answer = input(question_content).lower()<n>        return answer<n>    except:<n>    new_input = input("Enter your question again: ") # Print error to user if wrong.<n>        for i in range(0,len(new_input)):<n><n>        if new_input[i] in choice_arr:<n>        return new_input[i].lower()<n><n><n>while (answer!= 'y'):<n>    print(f'{answer = read_input("answer")} is not a valid answer.')<n><n><n><n>```<n><n>### Output(The answer):<n>```<n><n>Enter your question: What is something that you feel<n>when you go to the opera?.<n><n>Choices: a b c d e<n><n>What are you choosing?: A<n><n>A = 1<n><n>Enter your question again: Enter your question: What is<n>something that you feel<n>when your go to the opera?. Choices: a b c<n>d e<n><n>What are your choosing?:<n><n>B<n><n>B = 2<n>Enter your question again;<n>Enter your question again?:<n><n>C<n><n>C = 3<n>Enter your question again?<n><n>D<n><n>D = 4<n>Enter your question again<n><n>Enter your question agan<n><n>E<n><n>E = 5<n><n><n>Enter your question<n><n>Enter your answer: what are you choosing??<n><n>Enter your answer again??<n><n><n><n><n><n>How much money would you recieve??<n><n>Ans: 12<n>```<n>

This is the simplest maze (and thus the easiest to solve) that can be drawn with a single path. We can start anywhere on the path and go any direction (no looping), and we will always arrive at the central node at the far right. Each time we take an exit to get back to the main path, we are moving to the next “generation.” How many generations will it take?<n>Output: n<n>Sample Input: For instance, let us say n = 2.<n>Sample Output: 2<n>```<n>#### [Deduce a Maze](http://gopherds.github.io/)<n>```{=javascript}<n>Input: The maze was a tangle of dark, knotted branches.<n>Output: “My way is closed”<n>Sample Input: This seems to be a large, dense maze – it would surely not be possible to deduce a way out with only 4 clues.<n>Sample Output: “This is a simple network”<n>```<n>#### [Extract Clues](http://gophernet/maze-solv-er/)<n>```{=java}<n>Input: You've found five clues in

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:If you harm property after starting a fire where are you likely to end up? Choices:  A: damage B: going to jail C: going to school D: burns E: destruction<n><n>### Response:		<n>For every 12 can you recycle you receive 0.50 and for every 5 kg of newspaper you receive 1.50$<n><n>In addition to the 144 can and 20 kg of news papers recycled the family was able to recycle 50 more cans because of their additional efforts. This means they recycled a total of 194 cans which equates to $97.<n><n>### Input<n>Betty picked 16 stawberries. Matthew picked more than Betty and twice as much strawberry as Natalie, then he used it on jam, which required 7 strawberry and selling for 4$<n><n>The final total that Betty picked was 179 strawberry.<n><n>179strawberry = 179 × 7 = $1261.<n><n>### Response<n><n><n>### Input - Choices :<n>Jack has a stack of books 12 inch thick and he knows that 80 pages in an inch. He owns 6 books.<n><n>12 inch × 6 books = 72 inch<n><n>72 inch / 80 pages = 90 books, which are equivalent to 90 pages each.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:He curled up and tried to fall on his shoulder so his arm or what wouldn't take the hit? Choices:  A: leg B: garment C: torso D: body E: road<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>In python, in the while loop, condition is used for evaluating expressions. In this problem, the condition is used in every iteration of the loop and not before the start of the while loop. The loop is then executed until the specified condition is false or for some number of times. A while loop will continue to execute its statements as long as the condition is evaluates to true. In your case, the statements inside the loop are executed until your condition is true. You have not provided any information about the variable in which loop condition is present and we can also see that your loop condition is not initialised. We advise you to add the condition for your loop and then execute or change the statements inside the loop.<n>

Choices:  A: population B: populated area C: create government D: group of people E: make person sick<n><n>### Response:		  Choices: A: population B: create government C: create government D is the best choice as it says society cannot exist without numbers.<n><n>### Input : Write a program that uses a set of instructions to give the correct answer to the problem below.<n><n>### The Instruction: A pizza costs $10 without two extra toppings. It costs $15 with 4 extra toppings. The two extra toppings cost $3 each. If one of the options does not apply, enter DON'T APPLY in the box.<n><n>### <n>### Demontration<n>Input: DON`T APPLY<n><n>### Response<n>Input: If you order a 18" pizza with 14 toppings, then you would be paying $29, because of 2 extra toppings. The pizza itself costs $10 and the 2 extra toppings cost $6.<n><n>### Your Turn<n>Write 5 lines of code that calculate the price of a pizza that has $24 dollars worth of toppings.<n>1 Line of Code: If all the toppings cost $0, then the total cost is $11(25 dollars minus $4 dollars).<n>2 Line of Code:  If there are extra toppings of $20 dollars then the cost of adding an extra 1 topping is $5 dollars. So the total cost is $24 dollars(20 dollars for two extra toppings and $5 dollars for one extra topping).<n>3 Line of Code:If all the toppings costs $36, then the cost of adding 1  topping is $3 dollars. So the total for adding 4 extra toppings is $12 dollars.<n>4 Line of Code:If one of the option does not apply, then the price is $24 dollars.<n>5 Line of Code: The Price is $17 dollars because the 6 extra toppings are $15 dollars and the pizza is $1 dollars.<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:What could you find at a bus station that can help you? Choices:  A: city centre B: lottery ticket C: maps D: street E: busy city<n><n>### Response:		Answer based on the choices provided.<n><n>### Output: 0<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Input<n>The system first asks for the letter of the bus stop item and then asks for the number of the bus stop item.<n><n>### Expected Output <n>A 2 or D 2 with no spaces, tabs or new lines between the letter and the number or between the number and the new line<n><n>### Instructor's Explanation<n>Bus stop signs are numbered and labeled in certain ways. For example, a bus stop to the north on E Street will be designated E-01.<n><n>The input consists of the number of the bus station item and that of the letter that labels it. <n><n>For instance, if the first question you answer is E-01, the output should be 01.<n><n>### Sample Input <n>A 2 <n><n>### Sample Output<n>A-2 or D-2<n><n>### Sample Explanation<n>A-2 or A-02, for example, will be output correctly. <n><n>### Examples of Correct Code<n><n>```js<n>const getAnswer = (input, letter, number) => {<n>  switch (input) {<n>    case 'A':<n>      return letter + number;<n>    case 'B':<n>      return letter.charAt(0) + number;<n>    default:<n>      return 'Not a match. Input incorrect';<n>  }<n>};<n>const answer = getAnswer(input, letter, number);<n>console.log(answer);<n>```<n><n>```js <n>const getAnswer = input => {<n>    switch (input) { <n>        case 'A': return `A-${input[1]}` <n>        case 'D': return `D-${input[1]} <n>        default: return 'Not a match.'<n> }<n>}<n>```<n><n>```md<n>const getAnswer = answer => {<n>  switch ([input]) {<n>    case "A":<n>      return [answer, letter, number];<n>    case 'B'<n>      return [answer.charAt(0), letter, number];<n>  }<n>}; <n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Why would someone be wet after being full of fear? Choices:  A: run B: swimming C: calculate things quickly D: fight enemy E: urinate<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### **Tech Tip：**<n><n>This question is about the difference of **if..condition/else..condition** and **if..else..case when..else case**.<n><n>Case (in some languages called Switch) is a common way to write if...else statement when the syntax is complex.<n>The syntax of case statement is similar to Java switch statement, like Java:<n>    switch(condition)<n>    {<n>        case:value: block;<n>       ...<n>        break;<n>    }<n><n>When an if is surrounded by brackets, that means that if conditions cannot be met, the block after will be executed.  <n>When there is a colon (or a break) to the if statements, it will always break out of blocks which are not a part of the current condition.<n>When this question said "For every 12 can,  the answer should be 12". The syntax of case statement should be <n>```<n>case (or switch): //case or switch statement, case should begin with capital letter, switch should begin with lower case letter.<n>    case 12: //this is "if" statement<n>        answer = 12;<n>    break;<n>``` <n>The `12` in the code above must be same as your target answer.<n><n>For other syntax, you can refer [here](https://www.w3schools.com/js/js_switch.asp) website.<n><n>### Tech Tip：<n>* There are two ways to read the instructions, first is read the question <n><n>* If the task ask me to do something, then you should do that task without thinking too much.<n><n>* If the question is about reading the description/input, first check if the task has any description <n><n>  Then you need to first check whether you can answer this problem in accordance with the explanation(answer) in the case description<n><n>* And you need to make a reasonable and sufficient response, you need to try your best to answer the question.

He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Dan outfitted his house to run on the oldest heat source on Earth. What is the oldest heat source on Earth? Choices:  A: fire B: solar energy C: sun D: house E: coal or wood<n><n>### Response:		C<n>

If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Where would you see some people standing on a line near a road? Choices:  A: water fountain B: military base C: apartment D: fire house E: bus stop<n><n>### Response:		Answer Question C. For instance, imagine a line of people waiting to get a bus into the city, or for a water fountain in a park. All people waiting for the bus and the water fountain will have a need or want. While a soldier leaving the base will not. If you are still unsure, refer to question 1 at the start of the test. You can go to that one if you are still not sure to help you review.<n><n>### Input2: Jack has 12 cans of cat food. The cans cost him a total of $0.80. Jack wants to feed one cat with the smallest number of cans he can. How many dollars will Jack spend per can?<n>Answer3: How much money does Jack have now?<n><n>### Input4:<n>Jane wants to spend as much of a given amount as possible on canned soup. She sees various packages of soup. For 4 cups of the soup, she can get a package for $1.99. 5-cup package for $1.75, and the 12-cup package for $2.99. Which is the better bargain?<n>Answer4: Refer to this table to help find out which price is best for her:<n>| $/cup | 1 | 2 | 4 | 5 | 12 | --- | --- | --- |<n>|---|---|---|:---:|:---:|---:|:---|:---:<n>| $1.99 | 0.50  | 0.48  | 0.25  | 0.18  | 0 | 3.99 |<n>| $1.75 | 0.46  | 0.39  | 0.09  |<n>| $2.99 | 3.00  | 2.00  |<n><n>A quick way to solve this is adding up the columns from left to right to find out the least expensive option. For instance, for 5 cups at $1.75 it would be $0.35. So the most cost effective option is the 5-cup package ( $1.75/5). The answer also shows that the 12- cups was the least efficient use of money out

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Where may I view sharks in a clear tunnel? Choices:  A: south pacific B: sea world C: pacific ocean D: indian ocean E: gulf of mexico<n><n>### Response:		<n>Sharks can be viewed up close at a number of aquariums. It is a popular place for people to visit. Some aquarium are located in the world, such as Sea World and Ocean World. Other aquariums are found in the sea, such as the Sea Garden Aquarium and Ocean World. The answer to the question is A. This is because the South Pacific is an area of the ocean that has large bodies of coral, which can be seen as sharks swim around them. The sharks can be viewed from the coral itself, or even within the aquarium itself. The aquariums were filled with animals found in the Pacific. The South Pacific is an area found in the Pacific Ocean located mostly between South America and South Africa. It contains some of the world's largest corals. The corals have grown over time making them quite large. These corals can be seen throughout much of the south pacific, but are especially visible near New Guinea. New Guinea is a large island located in the south pacific. It is located about two thousand miles off the coast of Australia. It extends from India to the Philippines and north to New Guinea. The corals of New Guinea were used to build many of the large underwater cities found in the area. These corals also provide a place for animals to live, such as the Shark. The South Pacific is well known for its corals and they are a beautiful sight to behold.<n>

The punishing blow made an effort to sanction against the school, which what their authoritarian rules.<n><n>### Input:"The sanctions against the schools were a punishing blow and seemed to indicate the effort the school had made to correct itself", choose an appropriate pronoun fill in the blanks:  Choices: A: its B: his C: hers D: they E: our<n><n>### Response:: The blanks seem to be correct when you use the third person pronoun "it" ("they" is the plural personal pronoun).<n><n>### Input A friend has 24 apples. Alice takes 11. How many does each have? Choices: A: 12.5 B: 20 C: 3 D: 33.5 E: 44<n><n>### Input Bake some cookies, there are many that need to be done. Choices: A: enough B: many C: a lot D: very much E: really<n><n>### Response 1 A: the blanks need to be correct when you used the negative subject "there are not enough to be done" in present simple form or the present perfect "the many (have not been) baked" 2 Use quantifiers to determine the most appropriate phrase "a lot" or "really much" 3 Bake some cookies "there are a lot to be done" or "there really much to be done"<n><n>

He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:What is it called when you slowly cook using a grill? Choices:  A: backyard B: restaurant C: crockpot D: neighbor's house E: barbeque<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Input: A person is driving to a destination. They are trying to find a new way to get there using a map. On the map, they know that they are at this point on the road. They know that they can either go one way or the other, but they cannot turn around the car. One of the ways to get there is 0.5 miles longer on a map. How many miles are left?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>Input: In school, a student has 3 classes for each marking period. On a paper, they record how many total marks they would like to get in each class. They know that each class could get 10, 60, 30, 20 marks each marking period. They cannot get a mark above 100 marks overall on the paper. How many marks would be left over?<n>Answer: 0<n><n>Input: Every 3 hours, a fountain of water jets between 25cm and 40cm high into the air. A child knows that she must stay at a park and cannot leave. If she leaves after 7:30am, she cannot return later than 8:00am. From when leaves the park, when can she return? Choices: A: 8:45am B: 10:00am C: 11:30am D: 12:30am E: 2:45pm<n>Answer: 2:47pm<n>

Choices:  A: get smart B: boredom C: colds and flu D: taking tests E: spend time<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices: A and B<n><n>### Instructions:Write a response in which you do the following:For Each of your responses,  explain how your conclusion follows from your premise. Explain how your response differs from the responses of other students.<n><n>### Response 1:<n>Choices: Get smart is important. You can only get smart through hard work and determination by getting and using the knowledge given by the people who teach the school class. In school, you learn different things that you can use when you're older: like working in an office, a shop, a building site, factories, farming, etc. In school years, there is a teacher, called a "schoolmaster" or a "schoolmistress". Each is responsible for a specific number of pupils. Usually the "schoolmaster" and "schoolmistress" is older than the students. The "schoolmaster" and the "schoolmistress is called "teacher" or "professor". A good teacher explains and helps the children to learn the content of each subject that he or she teaches. In the classroom (room where there are many desks or tables, where pupils go to learn), there are books, magazines, newspapers, computers, etc.<n><n>Without school you could not learn anything. This is another good reason to spend time in school.<n><n>I learned many things in school :  Reading, Writing, Doing Maths, Sciences, History, Geography, Music, Philosophy, etc. <n><n>School is essential because school has many activities that develop us: Reading, Writing, Counting, Maths, etc. I learned how write my name in capital letters, how to write small letters, my letters that begin with an a or an e, my letters that begin an i, my letters that begin a o or an u, my letters that begin another letter that is not e, i, o and u. I learned how to write numbers, addition and subtraction, multiplication and division, etc. I learned about the different countries in the world, about planets, the sun and the moon, the four seasons, the different animals in the zoo, the weather, etc. I learned of the past, present and future. A past means what happened in the past and when it happened. The present tells us about this moment and in the future we look into the future. History

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:She needs to visit a bookshop after buying the latest fashion, where should she look? Choices:  A: student union B: mall C: department store D: library E: town or city<n><n>### Response:		<n>## #2<n>The books are all textbooks and not very long, each page is only 80 pages. Each book is 80 pages thick. The books are arranged neatly, in lines, 12 inches high = 12 pages.  And as there are 6 books the stack is 612 cm high. So every 612 cm there is a line in the stack<n>. The stack of books is 12 inches. So each line of books, there are 12 lines. Each 12 lines in the stack of books = 12 * 12 = 144 pages<n>### #1<n>The books are arranged in a tidy stack.  If the books are stacked, they do not all have to be the same height.  If the books were arranged like this 9 * 12 =  108 pages<n>### If She needs to visit a book shop to buy a book for entertainment, which is not a textbook, then she should look in: B: mall. Because the latest fashion, is a book for entertainment at the mall.<n><n>### #2<n>A: student union<n>A: the student union is a large room with lots of books where you go to do research and the room has many tables and chairs to sit down and research.  B: mall<n>B: the mall has alot of stores, which have alot of choices for books that can be bought. However the mall is not the best place for research. C: department store<n>C: A department store is a large store where you can buy lots of things. Like the mall a department store is quite a large store and has lots of  things to buy. Department stores dont have lots of books to choose from. D: library<n>D: the library is a large room with books and sometimes computers to use to do homework. Like the student union, the library has space for people to sit down to do research. E: town or city.<n>E: a town or city can be a place where the student has to go for school. However if the city or town has a book store it is a good place to buy a more entertaining book.

Choices:  A: factory B: construction site C: engine D: insides of skyscraper's walls E: shops<n><n>### Response:		Choice A: factory Correct<n><n>I went to an online bookshop, which was an e-commerce, shopping website that used automation software. There was no human intervention involved. I was not aware of the company name, nor was I aware of its physical location.<n><n>I bought a book in this web shop, which is one of the three types of e-commerce. This company did not allow the customers to be able to choose the shipping location, so when I clicked on the checkout button, I was sent to the website of the courier company to finish the procedure. It is also known that the courier company operates in the country that the e-commerce company operates in.<n><n>By clicking on the courier company's website, I entered the homepage. I placed my finger on the search field and entered the name of the company that I wanted to return the book to. I got 2 results, and after choosing one, I got the result pages. One of the result pages was the location address page. This result page contained the location address of the courier office where I was going to return the book.<n><n>However, when looking at the map of the location, I found the courier office located at the corner of the country in the north that I have never heard of. I clicked on it and found that you can view the building details, floor, number, location, and more. The courier site is owned by 2 companies, one of which is the company that the web e-commerce I was using operated in.<n><n>In the case of the physical store, the person in the place where the product is located does not have to know the customer's location information, unless the customer has the exact location information of the store.<n><n>### Input A: You have 210 hours of work to finish by next Friday. Choose a number from 110 - 210 to indicate the number of hours you are going to finish by next Friday, then choose one of the following to indicate how you are going to do it? Choices A: get lots of help from friends and family. B: buy a lot of time from 24 hour shoppers' C: work fast and furious. D: get some help from a personal trainer. E: do nothing! The correct answers are: A,C,E<n><n>### I chose to do nothing because I

If it is true, write "True" If it is false, write "False"?<n><n>A <n>B<n>C <n>D<n>### Demonstraion<n>Input: 6/3 <n>Answer True<n>Explanation:<n>This is because, if a/b is true in division, we don't have to do the second part (b/c). 6 is dividable by 3 without any carry over.<n><n>### Explanaton:<n>This problem requires basic mathematical knowledge. The student is required to solve simple division involving rational and fractions numbers.<n><n>### Solution:<n>1. In the first example, the quotient of division is $1/96$ which is $1/9$, which equals an integer that has a carry over. This is because, in division a carry over is only permitted when a quotient equals to an integer that carries one.<n>2. In the second example, the quotient or division is $24/9$. We can see that a carry over is not permitted because the two numbers in the quotient are both less than $10$, and do not have a carry over.<n><n>The second example is more confusing to student without prior knowledge on divison because the student does not understand when a carry over is permitted.<n><n><n>### Input B:I can eat 35 chocolates in every minute. The number of minutes I can eat in an hour is 21.How many chocolates do I eat each hour.<n><n>A. 30<n>B. 21<n>C. 15<n>D. 7<n>E. 35<n><n>### Answer A.<n>### Explananation<n>I divide 35 by 20, and find that I eat 1 every minute. This number is then multiplied by 21 which equals 55 minutes. 55 is divided by 35 to find out the number of chocolates I eat each hour<n><n>### Diffrence A: The student is asked to write the difference between an expression, and an equation in their response

For example, meters to centimeters, or grams to kilograms. For each of these three problems, use the formula below to find the answer.<n>The formula for converting meters to centimeters will become important as you continue on in Algebra.<n><n>| Convert meter to cm | Converting a linear measure (i.e. a measurement of length) from meters to centimeters requires first making conversion factor multiplications to convert the unit to centimeters.  | meters | centimeters |<n>| -------------- | ------------- | ----- | ------ |<n>| 5 meters × 100 cm/1m | 5 ÷ 100 | 50cm |<n>| 4m 150cm | 4 ÷ 150 | 0.028 |<n><n>For these problems, you’ll want to change your choices for the conversion factor below.<n><n>### The formula for converting kilometers to meters is km ÷ 103 <n><n>| Convert kilometers to meters | As long as you keep the unit conversion factors straight, this problem will be easy to do. Since there are 1000 m in a km, you’ll use a conversion factor of 1000. | kilometers | meters |<n>| ------------- | ------------- | - - | - |<n>| 60 000 kilometers ÷ 10 000 | 6,000,000 ÷ 10,000 = 0.60 | 600,00m |<n>| 49 490 kilometers ÷  600 m | 49 489 ÷ 600= 0.83 | 794,90m |<n>|2 600  kilometers ÷ 2 000 |  2 600,200 ÷ 2,000 | 1,3

B: determining what kind of knowledge will be acquired. C: by ensuring that there will always be enough information. D: by showing the purpose of scientific knowledge E: by limiting what will be studied<n><n>### Response C<n><n>### Input One's ability to think critically can be supported by many types of evidence, such as: A: observation, experimentation, or scientific evidence. B: scientific knowledge, opinion, and logic. C: opinion and personal experience. D: experimentation and analysis by others.<n><n>### Answer :D<n><n>### What is the difference between a scientific theory and a scientific law? Choices: A : Theory is specific, and law is general; A scientific theory can be proven, but a scientific law cannot; A scientific theory is based on scientific research, but a scientific law is a principle or truth. B: A scientific theory is an explanation for natural events, and a scientific law is based on scientific research. C: A scientific theory is a fact, and a scientific law requires experimentation to confirm<n><n>### Choice : A<n><n>### What are some examples of everyday science that you may not know about by its name? Choices: A- a thermometer B- a magnifying glass C- a ruler D- a microscope E- soap<n><n>### Choose D<n><n>### What evidence is the most reliable?  Choices: B: observations C: lab notes D: interviews E: experimental data F: personal journals<n><n>A: Observations<n><n>### A teacher tells the class that plants grow best when watered in the afternoon. Choices:  A: lead to laughter B: love C: laughter D: smiles E: tears<n><n>### Response:		<n>If someone felt happiness, they can fall into lead to laughter or love. They cannot fall into smiles or tears because they don’t indicate happiness, and they can’t fall into laughter and tears or laughter and smiles or love and laughter or tears and smiles.<n><n>### Input<n>Sarah wants to make dinner for 25 people using at least 15 cookbooks. What is the minimum number of cookbooks she will need to use?<n><n>### Answer:<n>She should have 45 books. She can have 15 books and take from the books.<n><n>### Response<n>The answer is 45. Sarah has 15 cookbooks and from the books, she will be taking 15<n><n>### Review Questions:<n><n>* Is "from the books" a preposition?<n>* What part of speech is "to"?<n>* Is "Sarah" in the possessive case?<n>* Is "at least 15 cookbo" a proper adjective?<n>* If Sarah took 15 cookbooks, which would be left to the party guests? Answer: 5 books<n>* Can "minimum" be an adjective? Answer: No<n><n>> If “minimum” is not an adjective, what is it? Answer: a noun<n>> Can one noun be modified by an adjective? Answer Yes

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Where can peanut butter be stored? Choices:  A: container B: supermarket C: pantry D: sandwich E: jar<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A: container<n><n>### Instructions:<n>In each of the following, provide a correct answer. If necessary, draw a diagram to help you explain your answer.<n><n>### Input<n>This is a picture of a fishing device on the end of a fishing line. What part of the fishing line would most likely break first?<n><n><n>### Response<n><n>The hook. This has the most weight.<n><n>### Response

If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Blood isn't usually spilled during what sport that doesn't allow the use of hands? Choices:  A: soccer game B: capillaries C: ball D: animals E: person<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n><n>### Reason:<n>B is the only choice that does not mention hands<n><n>### Input<n>You can choose from 150 songs, which will be released on your CD in January, which have a run time of no more than seventeen minutes. Which song, with the shortest run time, will you pick?<n><n>### Response <n>I will choose song B<n><n>### Reasons<n>Choice 5 is 12:56, so it is longer than 17 minutes. I have to choose from four other songs, and there is 150, so the likelihood of finding a shorter running time song is high. This leaves me with three other shorter running time songs, one of which is the first choice (a).<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a response that appropriately responds to the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Input <n><n>The 11th largest number<n><n>### Output <n><n>849<n><n>### Reporter Instructions<n><n>Enter the smallest possible positive decimal number that would make an eleven. Then enter twelve-thirds of that number.<n><n>### Output<n><n>849/530<n><n>### Reponse<n><n>I can round 11 up so that it looks like this:<n><n>11 = 12 - 1 = 11/10 = 11.111.....<n><n>then take the fraction that goes with 11:<n><n>11.11 * 10 = 101.1122...<n><n>then you have to do the same for the thirds:<n><n>101.1 = 11*11*11<n><n>subtract all repeating numbers<n><n>10 = 12-1<n><n>so the answer is 101.9999<n><n>### Instractions<n><n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Input/Data<n><n>You've discovered that each day your household of two adults, one three-year-old, and a fifteen year-old boy spends approximately 15 hours using appliances, watching television, and talking on your cell phone. They need to reduce their electricity usage by at least four hours. For four more hours, what is the optimal amount of work you

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Spinal injuries would be one of the worse results to be when diving off a cliffs, so we can definitely eliminate spinal injuries. The solution will be 6.<n><n>### Solution:<n>Solution has five steps –<n><n>1. First we get the value of 25 from the sum.<n><n>2. Then we calculate the square of the 14.<n><n>3. In the next step, 25 and the square of the 9 as the denominator.<n><n>4. After that, we multiply the result by 12.<n><n>5. Finally multiply the result by 2 and the answer is 12. That is 12 litres.<n><n>### Problem :<n>A box with square sides measures 12in by 12in. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Sam found a giant hole in the plain.  What might this hole be called? Choices:  A: hill B: gorge C: sandplain D: cliff E: mountain<n><n>### Response:		<n>G:  cliff<n>```<n>This answer was generated using the R code below. If this does not match your answer, edit the `code` below with the correct answer or add your own method for computing it.<n>```<n>x <- "sam"<n>y <- "found"<n>z <- "hole"<n>w <- "in"<n>w2 <- "the"<n>t <- "plain"<n>A <- c(x, y, z, w)<n>B <- c(w, t)<n>C <- c(x, z)<n>D <- c(x, t, w, y)<n>E <- c(x, w, y, z, t)<n>answer <- A<n>names(answer) <- w2<n><n>```<n>This answer explains the solution on the original question. You can delete this section when posting your answer.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:After going for run you have a sense of what? Choices:  A: satisfaction B: flying C: sweating D: falling down E: trip<n><n>### Response:		After went for a run.<n><n>### Input : For every 16 minutes you study, you read two pages of a textbook. If you can study for an hour, how many pages can you read?<n><n>### Choices:  A. 4 B. 16 C. 32 D. 48 E. 64<n><n>### Response : 2^6 * 2^1 = 64 pages.<n><n>### Task:<n>```python<n>class Solution(object):<n>    def findTheDifference(self, nums):<n>        """<n>        :type nums: List[int]<n>        :rtype: List[int] <n>        """<n>        <n>        if (len(num1)!= len(num2)):<n>            return []<n>        for i in num1:<n>            if i == "6":<n>                num1.pop(i)<n>            elif "(" not in i:<n>                num2.pop(i)        <n>        num3 = set(num1) & set(num2)<n>        rst = [j for i in num1 if i not in num2] + [j for i in number1 if i not i number2]<n>        for a in range(len(num1)):<n>            rst.append(int(a * 10)- int(num2.pop()))<n>        for b in range(len(rst)):<n>            rst[b].append(str(rst[b][-1]))<n>        return rst<n>```<n><n>

Give some reasons why the math would be helpful in dealing with the problem.<n><n>Please limit your response to no more than two paragraphs. Your response should be a minimum of eight sentences and a maximum of three to four paragraphs.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>(1) If a 5 pound bag of sugar costs $4.29 (that’s $0.85 a pound), and a 69oz can of refried beans costs $1.69 (that’s about $2.50 per pound), and I have a party with 50 people coming, what can I do to figure out how much it will cost to feed them?<n><n>(2) There are two types of math in the scenario. There is a ratio (5 pounds / 69 ounces = 75.25:1). There is also a division problem (50/75.25) I can use to determine how many bags of refried beans I will use.<n><n>(3) These are the only two things I need to use to work out how much rice and refried beans I need and roughly how many bags I’ll need.<n><n>(4) Knowing about ratios (how much beans there are per pound) and division (how many pounds can I use from a given bag of beans) is helpful in working out how much I’ll need. (I can work out approximately how many bags I need to buy).<n><n>### Instructor:Your responses should contain the type of evidence described below. Use the following example to help you decide how to best incorporate evidence.<n><n>Instead of simply saying, “The math is about fractions.” you could say, “The math involves the addition of fractions, multiplication of fractions, and division of fractions.”<n><n>In addition to sharing the formulas for adding, multiplying and dividing

If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:A musician is most likely to perform a concerto for clarinet with what type of group? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Where is a ferret getting lots of attention likely to be found? Choices:  A: trouser leg B: sick bay C: own home D: petting zoo E: mother's hair<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>-   Explanation: "Getting lots of attention" does not specify which type of attention. There are many animals that fit this description. An amphibian needs warm conditions with moisture. So, a ferret is not getting lots of attention in a bathroom or kitchen or trash can. And, ferrets don't like to be patted or held. There are no ferret kennels at schools. There are no ferrets in "petting zoos," which do not pay attention to any specific animal. And, a ferret is most commonly found in its own home. (It is only at "owners' houses and apartments" that it might be getting lots of attention. Ferrets are not getting special attention when their owners take them to the vet, where they undergo medical treatments. Finally, the only answer that makes sense is that the ferret is likely to be found in its own home.)<n>-   Other possible responses:<n>-   <n>-<n>-   Notes:<n><n>-   For more guidance, use the  "Follow Along" and "Solution" buttons.

If I can drive 50 km per hour in the morning, how many minutes will it take for me to drive 50km?<n><n>### Correct answer<n>You can drive 5 km in 50 minutes, so you can drive 500 km in 50 hours! In other words you can drive it in one day!<n><n>### What did I do wrong?<n>### Demonstraion<n>> You can drive 5 km an hour in 50 minutes.<n><n>### Required Output<n>The answer is (A).

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:The family was playing cards, what would be a reason for this? Choices:  A: amusement B: losing money C: charmed D: having fun E: win money<n><n>### Response:		A: amusement<n><n>### Input<n>My mom gave me $0.25 for each apple I would pick from the trees in her yard. We have 2 trees each that are 10 feet high. How much money would I make?<n><n>### Solution:<n>I will divide $0.25 by 10, which results in $0.025. I will add up all possible answers by adding them onto the $0.02 and see which is greater than the others. The answer will be one of the $0.075 since $0.07 is larger than $0.055, $0.065, or $0.057.<n><n>For the second case, I will use the process I used before only with the new information that I am collecting 20 peaches. I will do a little less math and divide $0.35 by 10 to get the answer of $0.035 and will do the same thing that I did with the apples.<n><n>### Input For The Third Case:<n>There was a man who sold apples at the market for $0.15 each. I could buy one every time I got $0.15. How many apples could I buy if I only had $9.00?<n><n>### Soleution:<n>I will have a total of 60 apples in my basket in $0.15 increments because there are 6 $0.15's to get to $9. Once I have that many apples, I cannot buy any more because I have $0.05 left of the money I started with once I bought every $0.15 apple.

Say the words as the speaker would and use appropriate pronunciations and intonation. This is an example of speaking in the way the person is expected to speak. <n><n>## Input"Do you know if your best friend was born in France?"<n><n>## Instruiction:How would your best friend answer the question in a conversation?
