How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:John is studying animals.   What is one of the many things he has to watch them doing? Choices:  A: bathe B: bite C: die of cancer D: obesity E: copulate<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```python<n>A, C, E<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>A bear is crossing the same road he crosses every day. He knows he has not crossed by noon and he also knows he won't cross after 12:01 PM either. What time does he need to cross by?<n><n>### Response<n><n>```python<n>11:59<n>```<n><n>## What's in it for us?<n><n>- To understand if the candidate is good at the specific programming tasks that are of key importance for this role<n>- To validate that an interview format and a way of solving issues is suitable for our company. If it's not good for us - it's not good in general.<n><n>## Do you use this at every interview?<n><n>It always depends - we always consider it before deciding if we will need to use this interview technique in a specific interview.<n>In fact, we are currently experimenting with new interviewing techniques. However, the way of solving the problem, such as using the Python coding in the task, is always used in the final interview.<n><n>## How do you compare answers?<n><n>The main thing when comparing answers is whether the candidate can present the solution and justify it. So we're more focused on the candidate's ability to express his view.<n>We are comparing the answers and providing feedback in a private Slack channel so all interviewers and even hiring managers are able to review it. We always provide as detailed feedback as possible.<n><n>## What if a candidate can't speak English well?<n><n>Our interview process is English-based - we use English to communicate about all the problems with the candidates. Since our product is primarily using English on the front-end and Python and JavaScript on the back-end, it would be much harder without the proper knowledge of the English language.<n>However, if a candidate is from a non-English speaking country we always discuss with him his English knowledge to determine if there will be any problems with the interview process.<n>So far, we have never had this problem.<n><n>## Do interviewers help the candidates to pass the test?<n><n>No, this is very important for us not to help the candidate during the interview and evaluate his/her skills solely to create the real-to-life testing environment and to find out if the candidate can pass the interview on their own.<n><n>## Do the

Choices:  A: new experiences B: playfulness C: own house D: good looking E: beautiful<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>###  Write a FOR loop which will iterate two numbers and will display the answer. Example:<n>Loop for two iterations 1st number from 1-10 and 2nd number from 11-19<n><n>```java<n>    for (int i = 1; i <=n;i++)<n>    { System.out.println(i); }<n>```<n><n>### Write a While Loop which will iterate the user input and will display the sum of its two numbers. Example for one iteration:<n>Loop two numbers from 1 to 10<n><n>```java<n>int a = 1, b = 10;<n>int sum;<n>	while (a <= b)  // while condition<n>		{  // body<n>	     System.out.println("Enter any number : ");    <n>	     sc.nextInt(); // read user number<n>	    if (a < b)     // decrement a<n>	            { a++;  }<n>	      if (a > b)  // increment b<n>	             { b --;  }<n>	       sum = a + b;   // sum is incremented by 2<n>	       System.out.println ("sum of : " + sum + " is :" +a + "+" + b);<n>	       }<n>	    <n>```<n><n>## Create a function that takes 3 real numbers. The function needs to return 0 if the real numbers are equal, 1 if the first real number is less than the second real number, and -1 if the second real number is less than<n><n>the first real number<n><n>```java<n>			public static int compareRealNumbers(float a, float b, float c) <n>			  {<n>			       <n>			        if (!(a==b && a==c)) <n>			        {<n>			            if (a<b) <n>		    				return 1;<n>			            else <n>			    		if (b<c) <n>		       		return -1;<n>		    	return 0;<n>			        } <n>			    }	<n>```<n><n><n>The problem:<n><n>Your friend is 50. Your mother is 30. Your father is

Choices:  A: countryside B: united states C: beach D: atlas E: developed land<n><n>### Response:		A: countryside<n><n>### Reason:The best answer here is one that answers the question that was asked.<n><n>### Input : For every 12 people who sign up for the group fitness class, they get one hour free at the gym. However, they'll only start the class once 30 people sign up. How many people have to sign up before the class even starts? <n><n>### Response<n>A: The first step is to remove the question words.<n><n>The number of people to sign up for the group class equals 30.<n><n>### Reasons:<n>* This is an example of a multiple choice question.<n>* We can see there was no question about, how many, questions were being asked.<n>* To answer the question, we have to remove the question words...<n><n>```<n> ...for every 12 people<n><n>  12 < 30<n><n>  28 <n>```<n><n>### Input<n>Ask me about my work in 364<n><n>### Response 2016 Work<n><n>### Requirements <n><n>### Instructions<n><n>### Solution<n><n>### Results<n><n>### Evaluate<n><n>### Review <n><n>### Future Work <n><n>### References & Acknowledgements<n><n><n>### Questions <n><n>What is the best way to use this tutorial as a tool for understanding questions on the ASVAB?<n><n>When are questions being asked that require a best response?<n><n>When are multiple choice questions being asked?<n><n>What types of questions would be answered with the given format.<n><n>### Resources <n><n>https://www.army.mil/asvab/<n><n>### Acknowledgements & Disclaimer <n><n>These videos are provided as an example.<n><n>### Attribution <n><n>https://github.com/NormBrown/Pennsylvania-Military-Asset-Mine-Tutorial<n><n>#16 - Introduction to the Task (30 min)<n><n>#17 - Task Demo (30 min) <n><n>#18 - Instructional Guide (30 min)
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:You are seeking to provide yourself what when you're applying for a job? Choices:  A: work B: employment C: income D: hope E: offer<n><n>### Response:		Answer: C The options given are incorrect. You can apply for a job offering the opportunity for a salary. The position is then seeking yourself the chance to have a career. You are then employed in that job.<n><n>### Input1:  If 6 of the people in a group were to be removed and 3 were introduced, how many extra people would there be in the new group? Answer1: 4<n><n>Input2:A: You are 7 people away from the number 31. B: You were halfway there when you accidentally skipped one number.<n>Answer2:2<n><n>### Input3: A 3-ft x 6-ft x 8-ft ice rink has an enclosed volume of 448 cubic ft. How many sheets of plywood is needed to construct it?<n>Answer3:106<n><n>### Input4:You must cut 2ft off a 22ft long board for an exhibit. How much will be left once the board is cut?<n>Answer4:2<n><n><n><n>##Task<n>Create a variable to represent 15.<n>Average the values of the two numbers by replacing the a letter variable with its value.<n>Divide by 2.<n>Create a variable to print.<n><n>##Thoughts<n>The question is asking us to create a variable representing 15 and replace a in a with a value equal to that of value. This is done by dividing 15 (the number we want as a variable) by the value of a, and storing the result in the variable itself. If this is done correctly it should print what we were expecting it to give us.<n>

You have to add all the parts together to come to an average cost of the items. $100 + 0 = $100.<n>### Input<n>How much does 30 grams of cheese weigh in pounds?<n><n>### Response<n><n>30 grams of grated cheese is the same as 27 grams of block grated cheese. 27 grams would equal 895 grams per every 1 gram when you multiply it by 30. $33.60<n>### Response:<n><n>### Input <n>**Input**: If you have a rectangle with a two-foot long side and an inch thick side, what is the area of the rectangle?<n><n>### Answer:<n>**Input**: John has a rectangle with one two-foot line and a three-inch thick line. Choices:  A: amusement park B: urban area C: airport D: shopping malls E: train station<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>**Input:** A<n><n>**Demonstration:** To get to this, we can make two if statements:<n><n>IF BAGS:<n>IF A:<n>   print "you park at an amusement park. You have a full day of fun!"<n><n>else<n>print "there are no amusement parks nearby. You will walk in the city."<n><n>This way we can give our user options to choose from.<n><n>### Input<n><n>The parking lot is too small for everyone. We need to choose 8 cars at random. <n><n>### Response<n><n>**Demonstraion:** For this, we go with the if statement in an entirely different format.<n><n>**Input: Picking an 8th car **<n><n>**Demonstation:** To make the car we want at random we can make an if statement:<n><n>IF (car=8):<n>print "You have chosen a random car of the 8th car in the parking lot"<n>else<n>    print "You tried for the 8th car, but you picked the 10th. You will have to go to a different parking lot to get a car."<n><n>### Inputs:<n>Write a Python program that takes input as two different sizes.<n><n>**The input to your program should be something like this:**<n><n>**Input: 10, 20**<n><n>**Demonstation:**<n><n>**If statement <n>```<n><n>def if_input:<n><n>    for i in range (i, 2):<n>        if i == 2:  <n><n>            break<n>        else:<n>            print(i)<n>```<n><n>Else<n>```<n>if i == 1:<n>    print("smaller")<n>else:<n>    print("larger")<n>```<n><n>## Instruction:<n>- Your task is to define a set with two numbers in it, so that the first is always 2 times larger as the second.<n>- The set should contain two numbers, A and B.<n>- A should be the sum of 2 numbers which the first one is always 2 times bigger as the second.<n>```<n>def set(A,B):<n>    if A!= B:<n>        for i in range(A,B+1):<n>            if i+2 < B: # if

When the print is done, end the program.<n><n>### The two print statements must be on separate lines.<n><n>### Use the following code as a reference. This program prints once.<n>```python<n>print("This is a Program!!!")<n>```<n><n>### Demission:<n><n>### Solution:<n>```python<n>def twoTimesConsecutivePrint():<n>    print("This is a Program 2!!!")<n>    <n>twoTimesConsecutivePrint()<n>print("The end of the Program 2!!!!")<n>```<n><n><n>### Instructon:Write a program that allows users to enter their age and select a gift of their choice. Display a message based on the users' input and the result of the gift selection.<n><n>### Note: Your program must always end with an appropriate message.<n><n>### Users must enter age as a positive integer and gift selection as a string.<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>Enter a positive integer.<n>Enter a gift selection.<n>```<n><n>## A program with the code of the instructions:<n>```python<n>age = input("Enter a positive integer. ")<n>elif age >= 18:<n> if giftSelection== "gift card":<n>    print("Cograts!!! You picked gift card. You are going to receive a " + giftSelection+"")<n>elif giftSelection == "prize" :<n>    print("Cognrats!!. You picked the prize. You are going to recieve the " + giftSelection +"")<n>else:<n>    print("You are trying to cheat!!!")<n><n>```<n><n>Answer: My attempt at code:<n>```python<n>num =  input("Enter a positive Integer.")<n>giftSelction = input("Enter a Gift selection. ")<n><n>if num < 18: <n>	print("You are too young to buy Gift")<n>elif num >= 18: 		<n>	if giftSelction == "

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:If there is a stale smell in the air coming from the kitchen, what should one check for the source of the smell? Choices:  A: bathroom B: house C: cupboard D: space shuttle E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n><n>### In the first line, I will define a variable<n>### the first string will define what question the user is answered, and<n>### the space shuttle will define the answer.<n><n>question = input()<n>answer = "E"<n><n>### In a while loop, I will input the string from the user and ask if it is true or false<n>### If the answer is true then I will append the answer to a list called space_shuttles which is defined previously.<n>### I will continue until the user answers 'false' to one of the questions.<n>while True:<n>  if question in space_shuttles:<n>    print question<n>    input()<n>    space_shuttles.append(question)<n>    break<n><n>```<n>### I will display the list to the user.<n>for question in space_shettles:<n>  print(question)<n><n>### Final output:<n>```<n>"What should one check for in the kitchen if a stale smell is detected?"<n><n>"E"<n>```<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:What is the purpose of the cabin in an airplane? Choices:  A: crash B: living C: slow down D: carry people E: speed up<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>* If choice: A, select A<n>* If choice: B, select B<n>* If choice: C, select C<n>* If choice: D, select D<n>* If choice: E, select E<n><n>### Instructions:What is 5/10?<n><n>### Constructor:<n><n>```<n># Main function<n>public static class Main {<n>    public static void main (String[] args) {<n>        Solution solution = new Solution();<n>        solution.answer();<n>    }<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Solution<n><n>```<n>import java.io.*;<n>import java.util.*;<n><n>// https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bentley_system<n>public class Solution {<n>    public static String input = null;<n><n>    public static void answer() {<n>        input = Console.readLine();<n>        System.out.println(input);<n>        System.out<n>               .format("answer: %d%n", readAnswers(input));<n>    }<n><n>    public static int readAnswers(String input) {<n>        // https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1642662/reading-a-series-of-integers-from-a-file-in-java<n>        BufferedReader br = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in, Charset.defaultCharset()));<n>        StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(input);<n>        int counter = 0;<n>        try {<n>            while (st.hasMoreElements()) {<n>                String temp = st.nextToken();<n>                if (counter!= 0) {<n>                    System.out.println("enter answer: ");<n>                    counter = Integer.parseInt(Console.readLine());<n>                }<n>                if (temp.equals("")) { return counter; }<n>                counter += Integer.parseInt(temp);<n>            }<n>        } catch (IOException e) {<n>            System.err.print("Error:" + e);<n>        }<n><n>        return 0;<n>    }<n>}

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Choices:  A: maps B: street C: catch bus D: city centre E: school<n><n>### Response:		 The answer to the task is "school" or "city center."<n><n>The purpose of the script is to read user input (the task), translate the task into an answer and provide that response to the user.<n><n>As a first step, get input from the user (as a string), and store it in `$userInput` as a variable.<n><n>Next transform the input so that you can process it. This may involve stripping off punctuation or splitting a string into different values.<n><n>After transforming the input, then use the `$operators` array below to perform the required mathematical operations.<n><n>Finally return your response to the user. See the comments in the operators array.<n><n>```<n># Array of operators<n>$operators = [<n>	'Add',<n>	'Subtract',<n>	'Multiply',<n>	'Divide',<n>	'Exponentiate',<n>	'ModularInverse',<n>	'And',<n>	'Or',<n>	'LessThan',<n>	'LesserThanOrEqual',<n>	'GreaterThan',<n>	"GreaterThanOrEqual",<n>	'EqualTo',<n>	'GreatEqualTo'<n>]<n>```<n><n>```<n>for ($i =  0; $i <  sizeof($operators); $i++)<n>{<n>	if (isset($operators[$i])) {<n>		for ($j= $i+1; $j< sizeof($operators);$j++) {<n>			for ($k = 0; $k < sizeof($userInput); $k++)  {<n>				if ($operators[$i] == "Add" && $operators[$j]  == "Add") {<n>			        if (string_compare($userInput[$k],'')!=" " ) { string $string $userInput[$k];<n>			       } }<n>			}<n>	        }<n>		if (($userInput[$i] % 8) == 0) { echo $userInput[$i]. PHP_EOL; }<n>		echo $userInput[$i];<n>	}<n>	if (isset)$operators[$i]) {<n>		$answer = 0;<n>		for ($k=1;$i < sizeof($userInput)

Choices:  A: thrift store B: bed C: shelf D: home E: toy store<n><n>### Response:		If you go to a thrift store, they may not have a teddy bear, but you can often find old and worn toys there. An employee would check to make sure the toy is in good condition. You need to bring your own money to buy a teddy, because it would not have an expiration date, as the stores only take their own money and do not charge the customer. If you want to buy a new teddy bear and get someone to help you buy the teddy bear, you should go to a toy store. A toy store would almost always have a teddy bear. The teddy bear in a toy store is also often in its original packaging, which the parent can be sure the child will receive in mint condition. If you want someone to buy the teddy bear for you, you should head to a home store. A home store would likely only sell teddies as a gift and would not likely keep teddies on hand all the time. The employee would be happy to help you buy a new or old teddy bear. However, that employee will only use the store’s cash, so bring your own to help pay for the teddy bear. The money would be inexpensive as it is only used for purchasing new products and is not considered expended. A store that only sells goods in their natural environment is a place in nature. The toy store would likely be this. A doll and dollhouse are in a different shape than a teddy bear and would not be a doll, so they are not sold in the same place. The teddy bear would be inexpensive and likely not sold in a thrift store. Therefore, a thrift store would not sell a teddy bear.<n><n>### Input How may times does 279 go into 1906?<n><n>### Response A: We have the same remainder: 1906 ÷ (279 x 1) = 1906 D: We have the same value: 1900<n>### Input 8 is to 7 as 39 is to what number<n><n>### Response B: 9 <n>### Input: You can measure the age of your pet by calculating how much longer their birthday is than their yearly age. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:You weren't suppose to touch the wild animals, they could what? Choices:  A: lie down B: run away C: bite D: keep alive E: feel pain<n><n>### Response:		"you weren't suppose the touch the wild animals, but they could lie"<n><n>### Input:"In the year 2399, Earth's moon is orbiting 4 times closer than it does today. How much would the Moon appear to move during an observer's lifetime, if the Moon is currently at a distance of 400,000 kilometers from Earth?"<n><n>### Response:"The moon appears to move 0.025 m during an observer's life. The moon appears to move 2.5 cm during an observer's 200 year life, If the moon is currently at a distance  of 400000km from Earth."<n><n>### Input": The last digit of a 3-digit number is 8. The first digit is greater than the sum of the first two digits. How many 3-digit numbers are possible? Choices A: 9 B: 8 C: 4 D: 3<n><n>### Response":"There are 9 3 digit numbers possible. The last digit is always 8."<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the question<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Input"A number when multiplied by 3 gives a total of 165. How much does the number equal? Choices: 50 B: 40 C: 80  D: 200<n><n>### Response"The number is 50."<n><n>### ResponseToTheFollowingQuestion:If a person weighs 2 pounds at sea level, how much does he or she weigh after a 1550-foot elevation. Choices: A: 2 pounds B: 2.3 pounds C: 2.2 pounds<n><n>### ResponseThePersonWeigh2PoundsAfterA1550FootElevation <n><n>### InputTheSumOfTheDigitsInA2DigitNumberIs7 <n><n>### ResponseTwice123AddsUpTo7<n><n>### Input10TimesSquareEquals10 <n><n>### Output:100<n><n>## Exercise 2: <n>Write a program that implements the two examples of pseudocode below and then compare their results.<n><n>### Pseudocode:Input: The sum of

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:You can share files with someone if you have a connection to a what? Choices:  A: freeway B: radio C: wires D: computer network E: electrical circuit<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>For every 12 can you recycle, you will receive $0.5 per can, and for every 8 kilograms of newspapr, you will receive $1.5 per kg. If your family collected $20 cans and $24 kg of newspaper, they have earned $$40. The answer has to be $40.<n>```<n>### Code Solution:<n>```<n>For question #1 we know that: (12 cans * 1) + (8 can * 2 ) = $20<n>For question#2 we have:<n>(160 pages *40) / 6 = 20 and 40*8 / 6 = 10<n>```<n><n>##### Reference :<n>[https://www.w3resource.com/faq/computer-fundamentals/computer-fundamental-trivia-faq-collection.php](https://www.wpsolutionz.com/learn/28369-free-multiple-choice-questions-and-answers-on-computer-fundamentlals-q50-q53-of-computer-fundamental.html#6)<n>

A, B, C, D and E would all be incorrect responses.<n>A is the only acceptable response. Input must be answered with one or more of the choices.<n><n>### Notes:  A, B, C and E would have multiple responses, but only one choice could be selected as the appropriate answer in the task response.<n><n>### Input :<n>I bought a book for $9. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:How does getting paid feel? Choices:  A: income tax B: satisfaction C: sorrow D: ocean E: bill collectors to happy<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Write a python program that prompts the user for a number of responses. Based on the number of responses you should<n>render and print a response.<n><n><n>### Demondration:<n><n>Input:<n><n>```python<n>from time import sleep<n><n>input1 = input('How do you feel about getting paid? ")<n>num_input = 3<n><n>while num_input > 0:<n>    print(input1)<n>    num_input = num_input - 1<n><n>print(input1)<n>sleep(2)<n>```<n>Result: <n><n><n>### Driven:<n><n>### Code<n>    <n>```python<n><n>input1 = raw_input("How do you feel about recycling? ")<n>num_enter = int(input("Number of responses: "))<n><n>while num_enter > 0:<n><n>    response = input1<n>    response = raw_input('Enter a response: ').rstrip('\n')<n><n>else:<n>   print(input1) <n><n>sleep(2)      <n><n>```<n><n>### Cleanup:<n><n>### Results:<n><n>### Output:<n><n>

Choices:  A: united states B: sky C: court D: field of flowers E: orchard<n><n>### Response:		If you said:<n> - A - Then you are right, bees gather pollen from their visit to flowers in a place called the "crop" (because the shape is somewhat like a crop of wheat or another food crop).<n> - B - You are wrong, although bees are pollen vectors, they are unable to pollinate.<n> - C - You are wrong, bees will pollinate plants to feed the larvae but will not feed on adults.<n> - D - You are half right, although bees will visit the flowers and gather pollen, they do not gather nectar for the purpose of making honey.<n> - E - You are right, bees prefer to gather from the more distant flowers but will also visit many flowers from their home area.<n> - F - You are wrong.<n><n>### Input :The following sentence uses a colon without a complete sentence, it should be : The sun rises from the east to the west<n><n>### Demostration : The sun rises east to west.<n><n>### Response : It should be : The sunrises in the east and sets in the west.<n><n>## Explanation<n>### Your code should include the `int` type.<n>### Your code  should include a function whose name is `computePayment` and is defined as<n>```c<n>  public static integer computePayment(int theQuantity, int thePayFor, int theQuantityDollars, int theQuantityCents)<n>```<n>The return type should contain `integer` which is a basic type, `thePayFor` should be a `double`.<n><n>### Your code shoudl use Java data types in all declarations.<n><n>### Write a loop until the 2nd argument is less than 60% of the first.<n><n>### Your class should have at least 3 methods.<n>### For the `computePayment` method return the value `0.00` if the second argument is less than 0.4, otherwise return `0.00 + the PayFor x the Quantity x QuantityDollars`.<n><n>### You should write a method that gives the current day when it's passed in.<n><n>### For the first argument, use two loops to count the number of pages of the selected book by checking for the number of

If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:If I had a jar which was likely to spoil if left out, where would I want to put it? Choices:  A: kitchen cupboard B: pantry C: grocery store D: pantry E: refrigerator<n><n>### Response:		A and B<n><n>### Justification: The kitchen cupboard is for kitchen utensils. The pantry is for dry grains. The grocery store is for fresh groceries. The refrigerator is for fresh dairy products.<n><n>### Input You want to make a salad. You already have lettuce on hand, which is 10 oz., and you find green beans in your fridge, which are 0.2 lb. How much must you buy to make a pound (lb.) of green beans and have 0.3 lb. left over?<n><n>### Response A - (1/2 lb.) 12 oz.<n><n>### Justifications:The lettuce is 10 ozs, which when cut into small pieces is roughly equal amount per serving. If you take the 10 and multiply it by 3, it will give you the amount of lettuce you need. The green beans are 0.2lbs, so 0.3 lbs would be roughly two servings. Let’s look at it like this: if every one oz in a can counts as a serving of beans, then taking 1 can, weigh it, multiply that times three and we know we have enough lettuce to fill all of them with beans.<n><n>### Other answers from the choices given:  A) 20<n><n>B) 52<n><n>C) 5<n><n>D) 16<n><n>E) 5<n><n>### Dear Kali I saw you yesterday, and I thought that you looked quite sad. Write a response to the product. <n>### Demonstation:<n>Input: When you take out a car loan, you have to pay two kinds of fees when the loan ends: closing costs on the loan and capitalized interest. To get rid of closing costs on the loan, you have to send the dealer a check for the amount of the closing costs. The money goes into a trust account from which the dealer takes his cut and then pays your bank. The capitalized interest fee is a bank fee that gets added to the loan if you don't pay it in full when the loan ends. This fee depends on the length of the loan. The money the bank makes on your loan plus the other fees and your money goes to the bank.

He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:If somebody likes temperatures cool, they might have more than one electric fan where? Choices:  A: home B: hardware store C: home D: hot room E: office<n><n>### Response:		The right answer is B (hardware store). The text says somebody, so it doesn’t say everybody. This means that it doesn’t say there are more than one fans in every house, instead it says that one fan is in more than one house. The sentence could also be describing that the question is about more than one fan and that there are more than one electric fans in a hardware store. The sentence doesn’t say how many fans are in a home. All the other answers don’t make sense, so option B must be the correct answer.<n><n>### Input  : Which is a greater value? 36 or 57. Choices: A  B  C  D<n><n>### Response  : The option C (61/84) is the right answer, because no other answer can make a multiple of 61/84 with the given value.<n><n>### Question - 10:<n>Input:  In 2092 there will be twice as many cars as in 2001.If you drive a 2001 car, how old will you be? Choices: A - 76 years old B - 56 years old C - 96 years old D - 36 years old<n><n>### Response : If you drive a 2,001 car in 2092, you will be 76 years old then. In 2091, you will also be 56 years old if you drive a 2.001 car. But not all years have 2,000 cars. If in 1992, there were 56 million 2,002 cars, in 2002, there were 108 million cars of the same size. In 2002 a car of the same year was 2 million 2,022 and 2,003 in 2013. At the current rate, it will take more than a century to reach 2,007.<n><n>### ANSWER-15:<n>Input:  How many times more electricity is used up by the computer in a month as it does in a week? Choices: A- times 3/8  B-times 3/8  C-times 12/24

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:What emotion do people expressing themselves show when they trip in front of a crowd and break their leg? Choices:  A: communication B: suffering C: pain D: laughter E: embarrassment<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is A: communication.<n><n>### Inputs:In an experiment, 21 students were given some extra milk. 16 of the milk was given away during free-choice training, 7 more was used for reward conditioning, and 4 containers were kept by the researchers to study contaminated milk. The remaining milk was then poured back into its container without being measured. What percent of the milk was kept and used within the experiment?<n><n>### Response to inputs: The correct answer is D:.080.

Choices:  A: bowl of soup B: serving dish C: table setting D: placemat E: glass of iced tea<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input :What's the first thing you look for in a restaurant? Choices: A: location C: good service H: high chairs S: reasonable prices<n><n>### Response : C<n><n>### Input:-27<br>17 <n>> 12<n><n>### Input  : If one foot measures 3 inches, 12 feet is how many inches?<n><n>### Response  :-3 feet<n><n>### Input :-40 <n>### Response : 7/12<n><n>## Explanation<n>There is one blank in the instruction.<n>Each input has several choices, but there is only one correct answer.<n>The question asks multiple choice questions, so there will be a corresponding number of choices to each question.<n>The output of the question is indicated by the last sentence that provides a sample answer.<n><n>## Constraints<n>- There are five inputs to be answered. <n>- There are at least two inputs that consist of numeric data.<n>- Each numeric input will consist of 6 separate numbers or less. Each question has at least 2 digits input numbers.<n>- There is no missing information in the instruction.<n>- There is at least one blank in the input<n>- For each output of the question, there’s an option to choose from

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:What does a virus primarily do to a person? Choices:  A: infect B: reproduce C: mutate D: eat food E: make computer malfunction<n><n>### Response:		<n>A- The answer is A; it infects. <n><n>### Detailed Explanation:<n>In many ways a virus is like bacteria. They have a central core containing their genetic material surrounded by a protective shell called a capsid. Once the virus attaches to a healthy cell, the capsid breaks open and releasen the infectious genes into the cell.<n><n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>### Demonstation:<n>Input: The word **"cobra"** has 10 letters. The word **"octopus"** has twice as many letters as "cobra". The word **"tongue"** has five times as many letters as "octopus". What is the most number of letters in a word with at least 4 letters?<n>Answer: 8<n><n>Input: Every time a student takes a test, they lose 5 points. Every time they go to lunch, they gain 6 points. If they started the day with 220, how many points did they have at the end of the day?<n>Answer: 62<n><n>##### Input: A student has 650 points to spend on books. If they buy 2 books for every 9 dollar, how much will it cost to buy the 8 books they want, and how many points will they have leftover?<n>Answer: -8, 175<n><n><n>##### Demonstation:<n>Input: A family is going out to eat. They budget $20 on food. Every adult eats 2 times as much as a child. Every 5 children eat 4 times as much as an adult. If 3 adults and 5 children plan on eating, how much food does the family need?<n>Answer: 240<n><n><n>#### Detailed explanation<n>Input: A family goes out to dinner and has an approximate budget of $20. Let **M** be the total amount of food for the entire family, with each child eating **m** times as much, on average, compared to an adult, but each adult eating two times more food, on average, than a child. What is the smallest whole number of m such that this $20 covers the total amount of food that the family needs?<n><n>Output: 240, because

Choices:  A: swim B: jog C: excercise D: work out E: rock climb<n><n>### Response:		D: work out<n><n>### Rationale:If the choice is A, B, C, D, or E. Choice D is the only choice that is a single item. This means the choice D can only be used once in the group, which results in the option D to be the correct option.<n><n><n><n>### Instructions<n>How can you get inshape if there is no land near by? Choices: A) Swim B) Jog C) Excercise D) Work Out E) Rock Climbing<n><n><n>### Demestration<n><n>**Instructions:**<n>How far away was the moon from earth?<n><n>**Answer:**<n>It was near the earth.<n><n>### Solution:<n>How far is the moon from earth? Do you live in the east or in the west?<n><n>### Rational:<n>Each sentence contains two choices, if they are in a pair, then it must be either in the east or the west. In this case, the moon is near the earth. <n><n><n>### Solution<n>What are two ways you can get in shape? Choices: A: Swim B: Jog C: Exercise D: Work Out E: Rock Climbing<n>**<n><n>**Demestration:** <n>How can you get into shape?<n><n>**Answer**<n>Work out.<n><n>### Raison:<n>In the question, there are two choices. Either you work out or you stay at home. <n><n><n>

Cape Canaveral Space Center**<n><n>### Input<n>What is the total weight of the books in a stack that is 60 pages thick? Choices: <n>A. 4 kg B. 24 kg C. 32 kg D. 100 kg E. 150 kg<n>### Response<n>**D. 100kg <n>```<n>$ 60 books * 60 pages/book = 60 * 100 / 60 = 100 kg<n>```<n><n>### Input what is the total weight of a stack of books that are 20 pages thick? Choice: <n>A. less than 1 kg B. less than 10 kg C. less than 3 kg D. less than 24 kg E. less than 5 kg<n>### Response: <n>**E. less than 5kg**<n>```<n>$ let x = 20<n>$ 60/x < 1<n>$ 20 * 10  / 20 < 1<n>$ x <= 10<n>```<n><n>## Input: How many cans of soup could you fit for 33 cans? Choice: A. 33 cans <n>B. 3 more than 33 <n>C. 3 more than one <n>D. 33cans more than 200<n>## Response:<n>**D. 33 can**<n>```<n>$ 33 can <n>$ 33 = ( 33 * 33 ) // or = (33/10) * (33/12) * (33 / 33) // or<n>$ 25cans = 33<n>$ 25 < 33<n>```<n><n>##Input: What is the sum of:5 and 10?  Choices:  A. 25  B. 11  C. 26  D.15 E. 16<n><n>##Response:<n>**C. 26<n>```<n>$ 15 + 10 +5 += 25 <n>```<n><n>15cans <n>+ 10cans <n>+5 cans === 25<n>or<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:He wore the wrong shoes while walking all day, now he has what on his heels and toes? Choices:  A: toy store B: story book C: great outdoors D: countryside E: wildlife refuge<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>It was a fond memory of a toy store with the name of the now defunt toy store in it "Giraffe."<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>In the input "When he was a small chiled he called the giraff mascot a cow, i was fond memory of the now deftuned what? Choices: A: toy store, story book, great outdoors, countryside, wildlife refuge." You should replace the underlined words in the sentence to correctly fill the blanks for the given letter in the choices. Choice A is a "toy store", choice B is a "story book", choice C is a "great outdoors", choice D is a "countryside" and choice E is a "wildlife refuge." <n><n>The above code is taken from my classmate [Dilip](https://github.com/dilip-p)<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:The old barn was beyond repair, they had to destroy it before they could what a new one? Choices:  A: make B: raise C: entice D: build E: fix<n><n>### Response:		 For each person who signs up for this week's meeting, the company will contribute $10.<n><n>### Input  When the first three people finish their work, they will receive a bonus of $10 each for a grand total of $30. When the next three people finish their work they will receive a bonus too. Which expression can be used to calculate the total amount of the bonuses to the last three people.<n><n>### Explain<n>A. 10x + 10 + 10<n>B. 10x - 10 - 10<n>C. 10 - 2x - 10<n>D. 10 - (2x + 10)<n><n>### Response<n>100 * a - 10 = 30<n><n>### Example: <n>I can count to infinity. If I start at 12, I can count down to 1. If I start at number one and count up to number 10, then subtract the 10 from that number and add it to 1, and then count up by 9's, I can count to 1.<n><n>### Write a comment:<n>The reason why you can count to infinity is because you can always keep on going if you have reached a negative number. The smallest possible number is -1 and you just keep subtracting that from the next number, and then add the largest number possible in this scenario, which is infinity. You will always be able to count down by one. If you can count down, and you can count backward, then you can count to infinity. <n><n>### Example Input - You have a 43kg weight on one end and another 41 kg weight on the other end, which end do you pull on first? Choices: <n>A: 41kg B: 43kg C: Both are equal.<n><n>### Response - The weight closest to the right is heavier.<n><n>### Example output - The weight closest to right is heavier.

Choices:  A: utah B: south america C: new hampshire D: japan E: new mexico<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>if (choice == "A") return "you can see a desert lizard in utah"<n><n>if (choice == ("B") || ("C")) return "you can see it"<n><n>if (((choice=="D") && ("japan")) || ("E") ) return "you can see one in japan"<n><n>return "you can't see one if you don't speak spanish"<n>```<n><n>### Input<n><n>```<n>let test = {<n>   a : "a"<n>   b : "b"<n>   c: "c"<n><n>}<n><n>for (var i = 0; i < test.a.length; i++) {}   <n><n>```<n><n>## Input for each line:<n><n>What is the length of this string?<n><n>```<n>let string = "abcdefg";<n><n>return("this string is " + string.length + " letters long.");<n>```<n><n>Write a program that will print out "hello" to the console.<n><n>```<n><n><n>```<n><n>Write an if statement that checks if the answer is a whole number. He knows that 12 onions make 1 bag of potatoes. The width of the shelf is the same as the length of the carpet.<n><n>- The following are values: The width of an apartment is more than 1/3 of a shelf and the width of a window is less than 1/6 of the length of a shelf.<n>- How many windows does a shelf have?<n><n>Ans: 2<n><n>### Complete <n>- When the height of a shelf is divided by the width of the shelf (which is two inches), the result is five quarters.<n>- When the width of a shelf divided by the height of the shelf (two inches), the result is three quarters.<n>What is the total width of a window?<n><n>###

Choices:  A: school building B: skyscraper C: business D: grocery store. E: work<n><n>### Response:		<n>1. A: the city. There are many offices in New York City that can be seen from across the street.<n><n>1. B: a skyscraper. Skyscrapers are tall buildings that you can see from very far away.<n><n>1. C: the city. Skyscraping buildings make up a lot of the city skyline in New York. They are tall and are easy to see from a distance.<n><n>1. D: A grocery store. Office buildings are often found in city centers.<n><n>1. E: A school building. Office buildings have many windows, which are ideal for studying.<n><n>### Input/Output:<n><n>Input:   For every 12 bottles you recycle, you get $0.50. For every 5 cans you recycle you get $0.10. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:What type of water transportation is human powered? Choices:  A: turn away B: let down C: have to sleep D: run E: row boat<n><n>### Response:		Let down<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input:<n>**Answer:** Let down<n><n>### Solution:<n>```<n><n>function solution(question) {<n>    const types = ['A', 'B', 'C', 'D', 'E'];<n>    const questionTypes = question.split(' ');<n>    <n>    return types.indexOf(questionTypes[0]);<n><n>}<n><n>```<n>### Instruction :<n><n>Write a function called answer() to accept a string representing the question. Write a condition to determine if the user’s answer is correct. If it is wrong, print “Incorrect!” Otherwise print the user’s answer and “Correct!” as well as how many letters their solution had.<n><n>### Example :<n><n><n>```js<n><n>function answer(question) {<n>  const types = ['A','B','C','D','E'];<n>  const questionTypes = question<n><n>  return questionTypes.indexOf(questionTypes)<n>  <n>}<n><n>answer(123456789AB) <n><n>```<n>```<n><n>You are given two strings, a word and its reverse. A word is any sequence of letters with no spaces. Write a function that takes these two strings as parameters and then returns a third string that is the reverse of the first one.<n>```<n><n>**Input :**<n><n>```<n><n>121345<n>ABCDE<n><n>```<n><n>**Output :**<n><n>```js<n>function reverse(word, reverse) {<n>  return reverse + word;<n>}<n>reverse('word', 'ABCDE')<n><n><n><n>```<n>

Use the following code as a helper function and do not directly enter code or text. The input will always be a lower case letter or number followed by a newline. The output will always be the appropriate letter or number depending on the previous choice. The first line should use 'print('Enter a letter - A, B, C or D and press enter.')'. The second line should use 'A = input()'. The third line begins the while loop with the condition 'while A!= "'". The fourth line prints the following text as long as the user chose the first letter of a, b, c or d''(your choice)A"(your choice).' The fifth line uses the 'if' statement and the helper function that matches against the input to figure out which number or letter the user chose and then uses the input of the character they chose to replace the '(' in the previous line with their choice and then prints the ')' before starting the next round. There is an optional print statement at the end that informs the user that the end of the loop was reached and offers an additional line of code.<n><n>### Request: Print the words chosen by the input using the script below<n>`<n><n>    import math<n>    input()<n>    A = input()<n>    while A!= "'":<n>        if A == str(1):<n>            print("Enter a letter: A B C or D.")<n>        else:<n>            if 1 <= A <= 3:<n>                print("(your choice)A(your choice) ")<n>                print("Enter a letter or number: 1 2 or 3.")<n>                input()<n>            else:<n>                print("Enter another option.")<n>                input()           <n>        A = input()<n>        if 1 <= A < 10:<n>            print("Enter the letter, " + str(A) + " or choose an option.")<n>            input()<n>        else:<n>        if A == 1:<n>            print("(your choice)" + str(A+" ")) # Add a space for line breaks<n>        elif A == 2:<n>            print("A(your choice)")<n>        elif A ==3:<n>            print('(your choice)A')<n>        elif A ==4:<n>            print(("B" +

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Where would you read a passage but not write it? An array literal has elements surrounded by square brackets. It starts with "[", includes any element separators, e.g. commas or semicolons, and ends with "]".<n><n>### Input:(7; 20;"A");[7;@("7";20;5)][2]"@";["5";("25";40)][-];(27;6;"9");15]<n>### Output:(7; 21; 5)"A";[7;@("A"; 21; 25)][5];(27; 18; 15)"15";2]"@";[(19);"3"];<n><n>### Instrusctions:<n><n>You can create a nested array in Java by using an array inside an array. Arrays need to be declared with different brackets depending on whether they are a two-dimensional array or a multidimensional array.<n><n>Input:(2;3)[(-4;5;@["@";4])](5;12"S";["@";6]<n><n>### Instructios:<n>Output:<n>### A: (20"@";["@";@(3;4)])<n>### B: (@("A";5;"2"))(3;5);("B";7;"5")<n>### C: [20;(10;14);(-9;12)]<n>### D: [("A";(1;5)))("D";(2;7))<n><n>##  8.<n>###Instructions:<n>Write a program that will prompt the user for the name of a file ("File1.txt"). How many hours will it take?<n><n>### Response :<n>```<n><n>if (x <= y)<n>      return y -x;<n>else<n>      return x-y;<n>```<n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Jim enjoyed killing people, but he did it too often and the cops found out.  What might the cops do to him? Choices:  A: going to jail B: going to prison C: beat him up D: get arrested E: die<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Explain:<n>A: This doesn't make sense, because if he killed someone more than once, that means he would be going to jail for each kill.<n>B: I think that this should be the correct answer because he might get arrested as well, but I don't really think that the cops would get him, since he didn't die.<n>C: This could be true, but it might be just something that they might do to him as a warning.<n>D: I don't agree with this answer, because I don't believe the cops can kill him if they arrest him.<n>E: I think that this answer is not right because cops can't kill, they would just arrest him.<n>

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Where could a fungus grow and not be disturbed by sunlight? Choices:  A: under rocks B: manhattan C: toenails D: grocery store E: fallen tree<n><n>### Response:		A:under rocks<n><n>### Input : Where should you put a ball to roll as fast as possible without falling down the slope it started from? Choices:  a) Bottom Left b) Bottom Right c) Left  center d) Right Center e) Top Left<n><n>### Response :Top Left<n><n>### Input  : A tire is 24 inches tall. A muffler is 10 inches long and 6 inches tall. Choose the answer closest to how tall the muffler would be on a tire.<n>A) The muffler would be 26 inches tall<n>B) The muffler wouldn't fit on the tire<n>C) The muffler fits, but it overhangs the outside of the tire<n>D) The muffler is taller than the tire<n>E) The muffler doesn't fit on the 24 inch tire<n><n>### Response  :F) The muffler won't fit on the24 inch tires<n><n>### Input A tire is 160 inches around. A bumper is 9 inches tall and 60 inches wide. Choose the answer that's closest to the width of the bumper. <n>A) 78 inches<n>B) 63 inches<n>C) 58 inches<n>D) 60 inches<n>E) 75 inches<n><n>### Response B) 63 inches.<n><n>### Input Write a function for a calculator that will multiply the first two numbers entered into the calculator by the third number entered <n><n>### Response Write my_function(first_number, second_number, thirdnumber) my_function = function (args: Array) { var return_val :int = 0; for(var i:int=0;i<args.length;i++){return_val +=args[i] *args[i+1];}}<n><n>### Input Find the volume of a cube shaped container with length 5 cm, width 7 cm, and height 6 cm. <n><n>### Answer 334<n><n>### Input How many times (including 0) can you write 62 and still have one number missing? Answer must be whole numbers.<n><n>A) 62<n><n>B)

You’re such a hard worker. B: That’s amazing! C: Good job, I’m very proud of you. D: What took you so long? There’s still so much to do. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Where is likely to have a lot of fire extinguishers? Choices:  A: garage B: hospital C: boat D: house E: doll house<n><n>### Response:		Option B<n>[!INCLUDE[crabout](../../shared/includes/crabout-md.md)] A hospital is the most likely place to have a lot of extinguishers. An extinguisher is used for putting out a fire, so the only choice involving fire is "B". The exits of a hospital is another reason why a hospital would need more than three extinguishers in order for it to work properly. And also, a hospital is one of the places that have a chance of an electrical fire. And to put out electrical fires, they use extinguishers to put out fires.<n><n>### Input:"Sally is five and a half times as old as her brother, and her brother is one third as old as their dad."<n><n>### Response"Sally's father will turn __29__ this year."<n><n>### Explanation: Sally’s age is five and a half(+1/2) times her brother’s brother’s age. Her brother’s age is three times her brother’s age. Sally’s age and the age of her brother multiplied by three(+3) plus five and a half(5.5) equals six (+16). Six divided by three equals two (2). Sally is five and a halve times her brothers age equals two and a half times her brother’s(2.5) age). Two and a half divided by three equals one and a half (+1.5). 1.5 times a brother’s age equals 1.5(+0.33) times a brother’s(2). 2 divided by three equals 0.66 times a brother. Finally 29 rounded up is equal to 0.66(2) times 43(+43) which rounds to 0.67, which is equal to 29(+29). So, that is why Sally’s dad will turn 29 years old.<n><n>### Exercises<n>1.<n>Sara put 24 pennies in a piggy bank. At the end of 4 weeks, she put another $20 worth of coins into the piggy bank. How many pennies are in the piggy bank now?<n>```<n>Answer

If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Janet knew she was dying from her injuries because she could feel herself doing what? Choices:  A: sleeping longer B: getting cold C: death and decay D: change of color E: stop breathing<n><n>### Response:		If you look at a word like Janet, you can see the word has a "t" instead of an "i". That is because English is a language based on sounds, but not on letters. The letter "t" isn't pronounced at the end of words, it is pronounced to sound like the letter "d". But, in this case, we have an exception, because the "t" makes the word "die". If it was written "di", it would mean "be happy". English is based on sounds, so don't worry too much about what you're reading.

If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:Glass that hasn't been treated to be extra strong is what? Choices:  A: weak B: fragile C: forceless D: regular E: flimsy<n><n>### Response:		A: weak<n><n>### Input : The number of cats that are either pawed or scratched by Sammy is: Choices:  A. 14 B. 35 C. 29 D. 81<n><n>### Response : A: 14<n><n>### Instructions : The following table shows the ages for a few children and their parents. Complete the column for the children ages.<n><n>| Name for Each family | Mom's Age | Dad's Age | Child's age |<n>| --- | --- | --- | ---|<n>| John | 18 | 19 | 8<n>| Sarah | 15 | 13 | 5<n>| Amy | 18 | John’s dad | 4<n>| Katy | 16 | Amy’s dad | Amy’s dads age - 1<n>| Mady | John and Anne | John and Anne’s age - 1<n><n>### Instructon : Complete the column for each member's age.<n><n>|Age for Mom and Dad |Anne for Mom | Anne for father | Mady |Katy |<n>| --- |:---:|:---:|:----:|:----: |<n>| 18 |18 |19 |8 |16 |<n>| 15 |Anne |John |5|15 |<n>| 16 | 13 | Amy |4 | 17 |<n>| 13 | Amy dads age - 3 |2 |5 |<n>| 8 |18 | 16 |11 ||<n><n>### Input<n><n>The image below shows the steps to make a pizza box with instructions for its own use (shown in Figure 1). Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:They checked the weather one more time during the flight, they were on their way to paradise and wanted it to what? Choices:  A: look beautiful B: be happy C: change quickly D: occur here E: surprise us<n><n>### Response:		<n>```cpp<n>#include <iostream><n>using namespace std;<n><n>int main()<n>{<n>	int answer;<n>	cout<<"Please Enter How many Books Are On a Stack  : ";<n>	cin>>answer;<n>	int pagesOnAverage;<n>	pagesOnAverage = answer * 80;<n>	cout<<answer<<" The average pages on each book is : ";<n>	cout<<pagesOnAverage;<n><n>	return 0;<n>}<n>```<n>### Output:<n>```<n>800<n>51200<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: electric locomotive B: electric typewriter C: multi-coloured walrus D: electric refrigerator E: electric drill<n><n>### Response:		<n>```java<n>//Write a response that appropriately fills in the blank, or responds appropriately.<n>//Example: What does an apple consist of? Its skin, its core, etc...<n>```<n>### Outcome:<n>The program will have two classes: Main and Item. The main class will have two functions. The printList function will take in an array as a parameter and print the contents. The addItem function will take an Item class, its constructor will have two parameters: an item and its price. The constructor will accept one or more arguments to print the items that were added to the item array. The Main class’s addItem function will access the user-input item, the constructor of the Item class and the Main class will access the array that will store the items.<n><n>### Constructors:<n>The Item constructor will have two parameters, item name & price<n>If the user chooses an option that they choose. The program will access the value of the item that they chose.<n>```java<n>// The addItem method.<n>public Item(String item, double price){<n><n>// The constructor for the Item class.<n>public Item(){<n>	//Creates an object.<n>}<n>// The addItem function in the Main<n><n>// Adds the item to the list.<n>public Item(Item item){<n><n>// The main class in the Item class adds an item to the array.<n>public static void main( String[] args )    {<n>	List of Items item = new List of Items();<n>}<n><n>}<n>	// Prints the user input and prices.<n>	public String Item(){<n><n>	// Prints what the the price is<n><n>	}<n>	// Prices the Item and adds it to the list.<n>	}<n>	}<n>	<n>// The main class will access<n>// Choice is the user input which will be accessed by the addItem function.<n>}<n><n>```<n><n>### Additional Information<n><n>### How to run this code:<n><n>### Reference:<n>https://youtu.be/3ZXbhUrVW_w<n>https://yout<n><n>### Source Code:<n>https://github.com/hussain-j/AQA-JAVA-Practice-<n><n>### Screenshot:<n>![AQA_Practice_Examples](

Below is an instruction that describes a task. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:To properly instruct children attending school you would need a great deal of what? Choices:  A: boredom B: patience C: time D: teachers E: inspiration<n><n>### Response:		<n>Because you want your children to be attentive and excited learning for as long as possible. They don't want to go home or to sleep before the teachers get the chance to tell them what to do next. Even if they don't want to be there. They still need to stay until the teacher is done. The teachers are trying to give them knowledge. The teachers are trying not to waste their time on students who don't want to receive the knowledge they are giving for a reason. It is good to give the children an option or something to do when they aren't listening to the teachers. This is because they're not the ones who are going to suffer from the lack of knowledge they can't remember.<n><n>### Input:: A bookstore owner would like to be able to sell two different books each costing $20.00. He must sell at least one of these books each with only 34 in stock. The first book has 6 left in stock and the second book has 1 left in stock. How many more must he order if he wants to sell at least one of each type of book?<n><n>### Response::<n><n>There are 9 numbers remaining<n>(6 * 6) + 1<n><n>9<n>* 9<n><n>5<n><n>9<n><n>34<n><n>2(9)<n><n>58<n><n><n><n>&nbsp;

Do you get it?<n>var myVar2 = -2 // <- This is your 'Input' <n><n>  <n>// The following line contains the output of your 'Input'.<n>// The output might get shown on a webpage or it could be saved<n>// to a.txt file or anything else!<n>console.log(myVar2); // <- This is your Output! <n>```<n><n>---<n>

Write a command-line code<n>2. While True do:<n>```<n>    ```bash<n>    while True:<n>        break<n>    ```<n>```<n>To do it with CPython:<n>```python<n>while True:<n>     break<n>```<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. If the snake cannot move, it will display the snake length and print “Game Over”.<n><n>###Response :<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: For every 12 cans you recycle, you receive $0.50, and for every 5 kilograms of newspapers, you receive $1.50. If your family collected 144 cans and 20 kilograms of newspapers, how much money would you receive?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Betty picked 16 strawberries. Matthew picked 20 more strawberries than Betty and twice as many as Natalie. They used their strawberries to make jam. One jar of jam used 7 strawberries and they sold each jar at $4. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:What happens to people playing games? Choices:  A: winning B: entertainment C: happiness D: cheating E: relaxation<n><n>### Response:		If they cheat.<n><n>### Input<n>What kind of games did you play last weekend? Choices: <n>A: Monopoly B: Clue C: Chess D: Trivial Pursuit E: Clue Junior <n><n>### Response<n>I played monopoly because I like it. <n><n>### Input <n>Alicia and her friends each spent $9 on lunch. In all, they spent more money than they had. Which equation represents their money?<n>Answer: $$9-3-1=5$$<n><n>### Response <n>Alicia's money is $5. Her friends' money is -$3.<n>

Choices:  A: solidifying B: melting C: getting cold D: feeling cold E: skin rash<n><n>### Response:		You should always wear rubber boots and rain gear when the ground is getting wet, or the ground could give you a skin rash.<n><n>### Input<n>Input: Do not stand in the rain (don't/don't) or underneath the tree.<n><n>Output: I will go out now, and put on rain gear. If I see any clouds in the sky, I'll leave right away.<n><n>### Solution<n><n>I know this solution isn't exactly correct, but it gets the idea.<n><n>Comment: How are you supposed to know what the questions are if you just dump up a solution?<n><n>Comment: I wanted to give him a hint.<n><n>Comment: It wouldn't hurt if OP was to add examples to his response.<n><n>Answer: You could [check it out here](http://www.programiz.com/dsa/csharp-faq) :-)<n><n>Sample Questions and Solution Code<n>\begin{itemize}<n>\item a. If you write down the product of each of these fractions and multiply it by 60, what is the sum of the results?<n><n>\begin{code}<n>decimal d1 = (decimal)15 / (decimal)60 * 10;<n>decimal d2 = (decimal)20 / 5 * 10;  // 4<n>decimal d3 = (decimal)40 / (decimal)3 * 8;<n>\end{code}<n><n>\item b. Add these expressions:<n><n>\begin{pre}<n>d1 + d2 + d3<n>\end{pre}<n><n>and check.<n>\item c. Factor out the common terms in each of these expressions:<n><n>10 * 3 + 12 * 7 = 30 * 6<n><n>36 * 2 + 15 * 27 = 72 * 3<n><n>5 * 3 + 3 * 27 =7 * 21<n>\end{itemize}

Choices:  A: supermarket B: home C: closet D: mart E: hardware store<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>> A: supermarket<n><n>### Justification:<n>Because a shopping bag for groceries could only found at the supermarket(not hardware store,mart,closet or home<n>)<n><n><n>### Input : A 50 feet rope is used to tie a boat down at the shore and to tow the boat. At first, the tension on the rope is 90 pounds and the rope is stretched 30 feet. Two days later, the tension on 4/5 of the rope is 100 pounds, and there is then 120 pounds of tension along the remaining 1/5 of the ropes length. How much tension is exerted on the rope as a whole immediately after it was first tied to the boat? Express the magnitude of tension in pounds.<n>Answer: 105<n><n>### Input   : If 5000 gallons of juice costs $3.24 per gallon, and 2/3 of a cup of juice costs $0.75, approximately how much does the container of juice cost?<n>Answer: $0.1675<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input: A 50 foot rope is used to tow a boat and to tie the boat down to the shore. At first, the rope is stretch and tension is 90 pounds. The rope stretches 30 feet. 2 days later, 2/5(40%) of rope length is stretched 100 pounds.<n>The total weight added on the remaining 1/4 of 50 foot which is 12.5 foot rope is 120.<n>4. A. Tension on the 12.5 feet rope increased by 10 times.<n>5. The final tension on the whole rope( 50 feet) is 105 pounds.<n>

Injuries can bring professionals to quit during the sport if they do not know if they could move their arm because they are in pain. Another reason is mud slide because there was too much mud on the floor and people could not see in mud. How much money were they able to make from the strawberries they picked?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jack has a stack of books that is 12 inches thick. He knows from experience that 80 pages is one inch thick. If he has 6 books, how many pages is each one on average?<n>Answer: 160<n><n>### Input:My favorite type of entertainment are rollercoasters and ferris wheels, where should I go? Choices:  A: theatre B: fairgrounds C: friend's house D: show E: casino<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```<n>I go to theatre the most because it is most interesting but I go to fairgrounds the most during summertime<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:Write a code that adds the input words to a list. If a word exists in the list, do not add it again. Print out the first 20 words from the list to the console.<n><n>### Input :<n><n>a<n><n>```<n>b<n>c<n>```<n><n>## Solution<n><n>```<n>//This program runs a simple speller to check for misspellings<n>//It then creates the List with the words used from the console<n>//It then checks to see if a word in the list exists, if not add word to the list<n>//finally print the top 20 of the list to the console<n>//Input (user input) accepts input with a blank for the word in front of "a", "b", or "c"<n><n>List<String> list = [];<n>//create list of words<n>String input;<n>//store word into the list<n>do {<n>  input = stdin.readLineSync();<n>} while (input!= "");<n>//Store into the list any words from the console, only accept valid words<n>String word = input.toLowerCase().trim();<n>String loweredWord;<n>//lower the word that was stored in the input to ensure no upper or lower case letters<n>if (word!= null) {<n>if (list.contains(word)) {<n>print("Found " + word + ".");<n>}<n>print("This word was not in the list or the input " + loweredWord +.". ");<n>} else {<n>print("No valid words exist in the list.");<n>}<n>for (var item in list) {<n>print("word value from list: " + item);<n>}<n>list.sort();<n>//sorts the list<n>final int topCount = 20;<n>for (var i = 0; i < topCount; i++) {<n>final String item = list[i];<n>print("item = $item");<n>}<n>```<n><n>

(This means that you are limited to using the letters a,b,c or d) You always want to spell your name, so always leave a space for the "O" and a space for the "E". Once you have done that the only letters you will have to use are A, B, C, or D.<n>1. You have the letters A, D, C, B, and B.<n>2. You want to put your name on the board as quickly as possible and the last letter you type into the letter bank should always be a good letter to put after the O to prevent running out of letters to use. (O-E = OE)<n>3. How many different names can you make with these 5 letters?<n><n>### Answer<n>6<n><n>#Challenge:Give a response that answers the question below.<n><n>## Instruction<n>Find an efficient way to find all pairs of consecutive elements in a range that sum to a given value in the range.<n>* range of a number is the range from the smallest to the largest number.<n>* [1,10] is a sequence range, and [10.1,20] is a set.<n><n>Example: Input: 2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9,14 Output: 14,15,16,17<n><n>Answer:<n><n><img src="./resources/2.png" width="600" height="200"><n><n># Challenge:Give a response for the instruction below. Input: For the sequence [1,2,3,4,-1], the sum is 4.<n><n>## Instructions<n>In C#, use only the built-in operators in C#, not your own functions to find and then print all pair-wise combinations of elements in an array which add up to the same (given) target number as the original sum (4 in this case).<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>```csharp<n>int[] arr = new int[6];<n>arr[0] = 1;<n>arr[1] = 2;<n>arr[2] = 3;<n>arr[3] = 4;<n>arr[4]

Choices:  A: farm B: ancient rome C: history book D: poor countries E: plantation<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Input:What were southern institutions were slaves do the labor called. Choices: A:farm; B: ancient Rome; C: history book; D: Poor countries; E: plantation.<n>This code only checks a specific answer,so if you answer as A:farm, the output doesn’t change.<n><n>### Your Response:<n><n>### Input<n>In this situation i choose the B:ancient rome, but this program needs to check multiple answers, so when I choose A:farm, it is a correct answer and when I choose E:plantation the output should show the correct answer which is A:farm. <n><n>### Output:<n>I added if condition with else for each letters. If we check that if the user response is ancient rome it will give output A:farm and if there is no correct answer we will give the wrong answer. <n>When the condition is: <n>```<n>else:<n>    message += "That is incorrect."<n>    <n>}<n>```<n>but we want to keep the logic so: <n>```<n>    else:<n>        message += "That is not an option."<n><n>```<n>We use this for when the answer is not correct, and this is working.<n><n><n><script async src="https://pagead2.googlesyndication.com/pagead/js/adsbygoogle.js"></script> <n><ins class="adsbygoogle" <n>style="display:block" <n>data-ad-client="ca-pub-3118188653220628" <n>data-adv-layout="in-article" <n>data-action="ad_image" data-ad-format="fluid" <n>data-target="csm_1450302" <n>data-ci-src="https://www.blogger.com/1800000057768334688" <n>data:adsbygoogle="exp:adID:csm_1406325;exp:cpckey:ca-pub-3427554490211397;ad:title,description;region"; <n>data:"client":"ca-pub-30062
